placeMetadata.name: Bara Imambara

sources.snippet: Counted among the top historical places in Lucknow, Bara Imambara aka Asafi Imambara is a historical monument that dates back to 1784. Built by Asaf-ud-Daula, one of the renowned Nawabs of Awadh, the complex comprises a large mosque (Asfi Mosque), a labyrinth (the Bhul Bhulaiya), and a stepwell with running water (Shahi Baoli). The structure boasts of two large gateways that will lead you to the central hall, which is touted to be the largest vaulted chamber in the world.
sources.shortName: Top 25 Places To Visit In Lucknow (2024): Entry Fee, Timings

sources.snippet: Bara Imambara is one of the most famous historical places in Lucknow. Also known as Asfi Imambara, after the name of the Nawab of Lucknow who got it constructed, it is an important place of worship for the Muslims who come here every year to celebrate the religious festival of Muharram. The Imambara is especially known for its incredible maze, known as Bhul Bhulaiya locally, which is located in the upper floor of the monument.
sources.shortName: 18 Top Historical Places in Lucknow

sources.snippet: One structure they commissioned was Bara Imambara, a massive complex led by ruler Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula with the legendary Bhool Bhulaiya labyrinth as its centerpiece. Some other acclaimed sites include Rumi Darwaza gate, Husainabad Clock Tower and Chota Imambara monument.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bara Imambara, also known as Asafi Imambara, is a grand architectural marvel built by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula in the late 18th century. This historical monument in Lucknow features a large mosque, a labyrinth called Bhul Bhulaiya, and a stepwell with running water. The central hall of Bara Imambara is renowned as the largest vaulted chamber globally and is devoid of any woodwork except for its interior galleries.

Historical mugal palace and worship place at Lucknow. The Bhool Bhulaiya in Bara Imambara in Lucknow is a labyrinth of interconnected tunnels, with each path branching into many others and only one leads to the exit. It is a must visit as the exiting the labyrinth will be challenging and time consuming. Place is maintained well and organised crowd management by the authorities are appreciative.

A place with picture worthy views but  mismanaged by authorities

I was born in Lucknow, and I am a local.
Today I visited the Imambara 3rd time in my life, last visit was in 2008 and these are the below things I observed.
1. There is no  baggage or security check. This place is piece of cake for any one with bad intentions or wants to cause havoc.
2. Ticket price for adults is INR 50 which is ok but for visiting the roof area or the bhool bhulaiyaa, a guide has to be hired which will cost minimum INR 100.
3. Before entering the Imambara or the bhool bhulaiya everyone must deposit his/her shoes outside the inner Imambara entrance and the men at the deposit counter will say "jo dena ho dede" which means the price for security deposit is not fixed and they mostly keep shoes and slippers in open. If there is rain the shoes can get wet. There is no proper cloak room.
4. Since taking guide is mandatory for bhool bhulaiya we had to forcefully do so and the guide will take you and show you the various holy things kept in Imambara. The guide that we got was named Raja Hindustani and his diction was not at all clear. He took us on the narrow paths made of the dome of the Imambara without footwear and there was no lights and the floor is broken at places and can cause cuts and bruises. The maintenance of this place is worst I have ever experienced. I will suggest not to take small kids here and that too on a weekend. My 4 year daughter was feeling scared and also this place is not for claustrophobic people.
5. Our guide passed a comment too on my wife which she opposed and yelled at him after which our group consisting of 40 people praised and clapped for my wife as she vented out at the guide who all the group members were forced to follow even though his way of explaining things or tackling crowd was pathetic. Many women came and told my wife " good you shouted at him " as all of the people were frustrated but not speaking up against the unruly behaviour of the guide.
6. Since the roof is all stones and everywhere it is hard and uneven , walking on it for kids is very hard and chances of getting hurt are high.
7. Nevertheless it is a picturesque place and if you hire a proper guide who takes more money your experience can be better but the forced guide system and no light being in the narrow pathways is risky for women.
The forced guide will charge INR 150 for complete tour.
8. Now my next visit maybe after next 15 16 years and if given a chance may not visit at all.
I love Lucknow for the food and culture but at present taking some outsider to this place may only cause you embarrassment. They should install lights in dark pathways and remove the mandate of removing shoes on the roof of the building as it causes huge discomfort to tourists. The renovation from outside makes the building look pretty.

Bada Imambara, the "Pride of Lucknow" is a majestic architectural masterpiece, built by the aristocratic Nawabs many centuries ago. I got the opportunity to visit this place and its entry ticket gives you access to visit other nearby iconic destinations too, like Chota Imambara, Shahi Bauli, Bhool Bhulaiya etc. In the Bada Imambara you are required to deposit your shoes in the shoe counter before entering its many impressive sections. One important point to note is that they don't allow unmarried couples to enter Bhool Bhulaiya without hiring a guide.
Overall, it's a spectacular place to visit in Lucknow!üí´

Of course! Here is a glowing, detailed review of the Bara Imambara in Lucknow, written from the perspective of a captivated visitor.

---

A Masterpiece of Architecture and Emotion: The Bara Imambara is Unmissable

‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ A Spellbinding Journey into Lucknow's Soul

If there is one place that captures the grandeur, the melancholy, and the ingenious spirit of Old Lucknow, it is the Bara Imambara. My visit here was not just a tick on a tourist checklist; it was a profound and moving experience that stayed with me long after I left.

What Makes it Breathtaking:

¬∑ Architectural Marvel: Built in the 18th century by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula as a famine relief project, this isn't just a building; it's a statement. The central hall, the Bhul-Bhulaiya, is the undisputed star. It‚Äôs the world's largest unsupported vaulted chamber‚Äîa fact that becomes awe-inspiring once you stand under its colossal, gravity-defying ceiling. The absence of any beams or pillars is an engineering miracle that will leave you staring upwards in wonder.
¬∑ The Labyrinth (Bhul-Bhulaiya): This is an adventure like no other! The complex network of over 1000 narrow passageways, stairways, and dead ends across three floors is brilliantly confusing. A guide is highly recommended‚Äînot just to find your way out, but to hear the fascinating stories of secret tunnels (some leading to Delhi, Allahabad, and even the river Gomti!), acoustic tricks where a whisper travels from one end to the other, and the strategic purpose this maze served. It‚Äôs incredibly fun and a little thrilling!
¬∑ The Grand Scale and Symmetry: The entire complex is a lesson in grandeur. From the majestic Baoli (stepwell) with its hauntingly beautiful reflection in the water to the towering Rumi Darwaza (a few steps away, often considered a part of the complex), every structure is built on an epic scale. The symmetry of the main Imambara, reflected in the large water tank in front of it, makes for stunning photographs.
¬∑ A Place of Peace and Spirit: Despite the crowds, there are corners of serene tranquility. The main hall is a sacred Shia Muslim congregation space, especially during Muharram. The atmosphere is one of deep respect and peace. The views from the top of the labyrinth, overlooking the old city of Lucknow, are simply priceless.

A Few Tips for Your Visit:

¬∑ Hire a Guide: Seriously, do it. They are available at the entrance and for a reasonable fee, they bring the history and secrets of the Imambara to life. The stories and facts they share are invaluable.
¬∑ Wear Comfortable Shoes: You will be climbing a lot of stairs, especially in the Bhul-Bhulaiya.
¬∑ Best Time to Visit: Early morning or late afternoon to avoid the peak heat and crowds. The golden hour light makes the sandstone glow beautifully.
¬∑ Combine Your Visit: The beautiful Chota Imambara and the British Residency are nearby and together they complete the story of historic Lucknow.

In Conclusion:

The Bara Imambara is more than stone and mortar. It is a testament to human compassion (built for a famine relief), architectural genius, and the rich cultural tapestry of Lucknow. It engages you physically, intellectually, and emotionally. It is, without a doubt, the heart and soul of the city and an absolute must-visit for anyone traveling to India.

You don't just see the Bara Imambara; you feel it. And that feeling is unforgettable.

Though we were not allowed in due to a religious event there, the building frok outside looked beautiful. However, the entrance to it, the road leading to it, the adjoining places of interest were extremely dirty and filthy with no maintenance done for years it seems. Such great heritage is totally neglected.

Visiting Bara Imambara in Lucknow was like stepping back into history. The moment I walked inside, I was struck by the sheer grandeur of the architecture. The huge central hall, built without the support of beams, felt both overwhelming and mesmerizing. Every corner had a story hidden in its arches, walls, and intricate designs.
The Bhool Bhulaiya was one of the most fascinating parts. Walking through the narrow passageways, turning corners, and finding hidden staircases felt adventurous‚Äîalmost like being transported into another era. It was both thrilling and slightly mysterious, knowing that people hundreds of years ago had walked the same paths. After weaving through its narrow corridors and hidden stairways, I reached the terrace. The moment I looked out from the jharokha, I was left speechless‚Äîthe view was simply breathtaking.Seeing the gardens, the minarets, and the cityscape framed in heritage architecture made me realize why this monument is considered the pride of Lucknow.
The whole experience was more than just sightseeing‚Äîit was about feeling the Nawabi charm, the artistry, and the timelessness of a place that still stands tall after centuries. Bara Imambara isn‚Äôt just a monument, it‚Äôs a reminder of how beautifully history and culture live on in the heart of Lucknow. üåø‚ú®

Beautiful heritage site with stunning Mughal architecture. The Bhul Bhulaiya maze and the grand central hall are must-see highlights. Well-maintained, informative, and a must-visit spot in Lucknow.
As a visitor from Kolkata, I truly enjoyed exploring the heritage of Lucknow.

placeMetadata.name: Chowk

sources.snippet: Head off to Chowk, another popular and age-old market in Lucknow that exudes an unmistakable Awadhi vibe. With over 5000 shops, the place offers you a great street shopping experience as well as a glimpse into the city‚Äôs cultural heritage. From stunning chikan and zardozi garments, handmade jewelry, Nagra footwear, and perfumes, to melt-in-the-mouth kebabs, tasty biriyanis, and rabris, you can find it all in Chowk.

placeMetadata.name: Rumi Darwaza

sources.snippet: When you want to witness the grandeur of the Awadhi style of architecture, make your way to the Rumi Darwaza, an imposing gateway located between Bara Imambara and Chota Imambara. This gateway built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula is about 60-feet tall and is generally used as the logo for Lucknow city. Since the gate is modeled after the Sublime Porte in Istanbul, it is sometimes referred to as the Turkish Gate.
sources.shortName: Top 25 Places To Visit In Lucknow (2024): Entry Fee, Timings

sources.snippet: The Rumi Darwaza was built in 1784-86 and is a 60 feet high entrance, with no visible supporting fittings. It is also known as the Turkish Gate and displays Awadhi architectural style.

reviews.reviewText:
Rumi Darwaza, one of Lucknow‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, stands as a majestic symbol of the city‚Äôs rich Nawabi heritage and architectural brilliance. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula during a period of severe famine, the structure not only provided employment to thousands but also left behind a masterpiece that continues to awe visitors centuries later. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúTurkish Gate‚Äù due to its Awadhi architectural style inspired by Turkish design, the Rumi Darwaza rises to a height of 60 feet, with a striking arched gateway and intricately carved floral motifs adorning its surface.

Sadly, in recent years, the monument has undergone a round of repainting rather than proper restoration. The use of modern paints, rather than historically accurate conservation techniques, has slightly dulled its original charm. Yet, even this cosmetic intervention hasn‚Äôt managed to mask its beauty. The gateway still exudes elegance and grandeur.

What makes Rumi Darwaza even more intriguing is its resemblance to the shape of a traditional necklace ‚Äî and to those familiar with Lucknow‚Äôs textile artistry, it uncannily echoes the layout of a chikan kurta design. It‚Äôs a bridge between architecture and culture, the physical and the artistic. Despite changes over time, Rumi Darwaza continues to be a proud emblem of Lucknow‚Äôs past and present.

Recently Visiting Rumi Darwaza in Lucknow is an awesome old Awadhi architecture. The marvelous carvings and grand design make it a beautiful sight. It resemble to the shape of a traditional necklace and pendant. It's considered one of the proud emblem and most photogenic spots of Lucknow. If you are in Lucknow please don‚Äôt miss here to take a picture. Visit this place in early hours for good pictures and avoid crowd. After Delhi and Agra I found architecturally beautiful city is Lucknow. As the name suggests itself and some people called it the Turkish Gate. Must visit.

1.Architectural Beauty:
Visitors often praise the Rumi Darwaza for its grand design and detailed carvings. Many call it a "masterpiece of Awadhi architecture."

2. Perfect for Photography:
Tourists love clicking photos here. It's considered one of the most photogenic spots in Lucknow, especially in the early morning or at sunset.

3. Historical Importance:
Many people appreciate the deep historical value of the gate. They mention it transports you to the era of Nawabs and Mughal influences.

4. Central Location:
Since it‚Äôs located in the heart of Lucknow, it's easy to combine a visit with other nearby attractions like Bada Imambara and Chota Imambara.

5. Mixed Notes on Maintenance:
Some reviewers feel that while the structure itself is stunning, better maintenance (especially cleanliness around the area) could make the experience even better

placeMetadata.name: Dilkusha Kothi

sources.snippet: The best thing about the monuments of Lucknow is their diversity as these are built as per not just one or two, but several styles of architecture from all over the world. While the above monuments reflected Mughal, Hindu, European and other styles, Dilkusha Kothi is here to show you the magnificence of the Baroque style of architecture. Saadat Ali Khan, during his rule in the 19 th century, constructed this building, which is a complete replica of Seaton Delavel, an English country house built in 1721.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Historical Places in Lucknow: Check Timing & Entry Fee

sources.snippet: A hunting lodge converted into a summer palace for the royals, Dilkusha Kothi was built in 1800 by Major Gore in Baroque style. It faced major impact during the first war of independence and hence lies in a less than perfect state with just a few towers and walls standing.
sources.shortName: 18 Top Historical Places in Lucknow

sources.snippet: Palaces were commonplace in those days; take note when you see the Kaiserbagh Palace Complex and Dilkusha Kothi during your visit. Both landmarks are uniquely designed yet share a common theme of meticulous craftsmanship that locals are very proud of.

An often ignored rarely visited Heritage spot in Lucknow. Most tourists head to Imam Bara, Roomi Darwaza, top off with kebabs and leave. This historic baroque mansion which saw great action during the 1857 revolution period should be a must on everyone's calendar. Site facilities are however non existent. Drinking water fountains do not work and the main information centre and souvenir shop is now a glorious outhouse for staff. The lawns are reasonably well maintained and inner courtyards of both structures remain locked without explanation. Old signs of vandalism and brainless love scribbles exist as a reminder that a lot of people don't value Heritage.

Gripes apart, this is a must visit and barely a 10 mins ride from City centre. This hunting lodge cum Summer retreat for the nawabs and British residents alike would have been a vibrant place in the early 19th century. Hopefully the tourism development corporation would better publicize this place and allot a decent budget for better upkeep and maintenance.

Entry is free from sunrise till sunset but you may find the main gate locked till 10 am. Even otherwise, the gate was perplexingly locked with a loose chain which makes visitors squeeze through the gates. Parking is amply available on site for two and four wheelers.

sources.snippet: Hussainabad Clock Tower| #8 of 10 historical places in Lucknow. Nestled amidst Chota Imambara and Rumi Darwaza is another heritage of Lucknow ‚Äì Hussainabad Clock Tower. The 221-feet structure has been dominating the landscape of Lucknow since 1887 when it was built to commemorate the arrival of Sir George Couper who served as the first Lieutenant Governor of the United Province of Awadh.

sources.snippet: Standing tall adjacent to the Rumi Darwaza, the Husainabad Clock Tower was built in 1881 and since has been the tallest clock tower in India. It is 67 meters high, displaying Victorian-Gothic brilliance with a 14 feet long pendulum and a dial in the shape of a 12 petalled flower.

The Hussainabad Clock Tower is truly a beautiful landmark in Lucknow. The architecture is stunning, with intricate details that make it stand out, especially when seen up close. It‚Äôs well-maintained, and the surrounding area has a nice historic charm. Visiting in the evening is extra special ‚Äî the lighting makes it even more picturesque. A great spot for history lovers, photography, or just a peaceful walk while soaking in the old-world vibe of the city.

In the resplendent city of Lucknow, a towering marvel of modernity pierces the sky ‚Äì the illustrious Clock Tower, a masterpiece of Moorish design, erstwhile believed to be the largest in the Indian subcontinent. This magnificent edifice, a symphony of stone and steel, is illuminated by a dazzling array of lamps, its beauty further enhanced by the melodic chime of five bells, whose sweet peals echo through the air. Standing tall at 221 feet, this grandiose structure is an exemplar of traditional British architecture, rivaling the iconic Big Ben of London in both splendor and majesty. Its colossal wheels, a marvel of engineering, surpass even those of its London counterpart.

Conceived by the visionary architect of those times- Richard Roskell Bayne, this monumental clock tower was erected at a cost of two lakhs, funded by the benevolent Trustees of the Husainabad Endowment, who wisely invested the legacy of thirty-six lakhs of rupees bequeathed by the illustrious Muhammad Ali Shah, third King of Oudh. Bayne‚Äôs masterpiece, a testament to his ingenuity, boasts a intricate machinery comprising wrought-iron sides, gun-metal wheels, and hardened steel pinions, precision-crafted to ensure unwavering accuracy.

This majestic timepiece, a true marvel of modern science, stands as a shining beacon, a testament to the confluence of art and engineering. Its grandeur is a reflection of Bayne‚Äôs prolific career, which spanned the construction of bridges, train stations, and bungalows, as well as monumental buildings such as the East India Railway Office, New Market in Kolkata, and Oak Grove School in Mussoorie. His legacy extends to the Thornhill and Mayne Memorial Library and Mayo Memorial in Allahabad, a testament to his enduring impact on India‚Äôs architectural landscape.

Husainabad Clock Tower is a stunning heritage landmark and the tallest clock tower in India. The architecture is remarkable, especially when lit up in the evening. It‚Äôs a peaceful spot for history lovers and photography enthusiasts. The place is also wheelchair accessible ‚ôø which adds to visitor comfort.

Visiting the Bara Imambara was an incredible experience. The architecture is absolutely stunning, with grand arches, intricate carvings, and a beautifully maintained garden that adds to the charm of the place. It‚Äôs not just a monument ‚Äî it feels like stepping back in time. The central hall is massive and awe-inspiring, and the Bhulbhulaiya (labyrinth) is a must-try for a bit of fun and mystery. It‚Äôs a peaceful, clean, and well-kept heritage site, perfect for history lovers, photographers, or anyone wanting a glimpse of Lucknow‚Äôs royal past. Highly recommended if you‚Äôre visiting the city!

The Lucknow Clock Tower, also known as the Husainabad Clock Tower or Ghanta Ghar, is a prominent historical monument in Lucknow, India. It was built in the late 19th century to commemorate the arrival of Sir George Couper, the first Lieutenant Governor of the United Provinces of Avadh. The tower is located near other heritage sites like the Rumi Darwaza and Husainabad Imambara, making it an integral part of Lucknow‚Äôs cultural and architectural landscape.

sources.snippet: If street food makes your mouth water then Aminabad market will do more than satisfy your hunger, it'll create a puddle on the floor (I mean that in the most tasteful way). placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Tunday Kababi is a renowned eatery in Lucknow, India, named after Haji Murad Ali, also known as "Tunday" due to his disability. The restaurant is famous for its iconic kebabs and has become a must-visit spot in the city. The legend of Tunday Kababi dates back to a beloved Nawab who initiated a grand competition during his time.
placeMetadata.address: 168/6, Old Nazirabad Rd, Mohan Market, Khayali Ganj, Aminabad, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226018, India

reviews.reviewText:
Old is Gold ‚Äî And So Is the Taste!

Tunday Kababi truly lives up to its legendary name. The taste? Absolutely unforgettable ‚Äî just like the saying, ‚Äúold is gold.‚Äù Every bite feels like tradition served on a plate.

Yes, we had to wait, but honestly, for this kind of flavor, it‚Äôs worth every second. The service is quick and the staff tries their best, but the crowd is massive ‚Äî and for good reason! With such iconic food, managing everything perfectly is a challenge, but they still deliver a great experience.

Highly recommended for anyone who loves authentic Mughlai flavors. Just come with a little patience and a big appetite!

The service is quick and the staff tries their best, but the crowd is massive.
Highly recommended for anyone who loves authentic Mughlai flavors. Just come with a little patience and a big appetite. With Authentic food of here we also had mutton korma, which was not as I thought it would be. Though the taste was not that bad as well. Galawati kabab are so delicious as it is famous all over India for its taste. Biryani was completely worth it simple, aromatic, and packed with authentic flavors.

First thing after landing in Lucknow was to run to Tunday Kababi for the famous kebabs . Me and my friend was the first to reach and served. Ordered Galawati Kababai , paratha and mutton biryani. Kababi was disaapointing. I mean my expectation were sky high found out to be Meh. Biryani was good. Mutton a bit chewy but super  liked it.

I tried galawti at other places too and found those to be better.

It is a much hyped place, which I thought would be worth visiting, but it was not that worth. I visited them around fifteen years ago, and it was much different and better then. The food didn't have the old time charm. The galawati kebabs are no more melt into mouth as they used to be earlier. We also had mutton korma, which again was not as I thought it would be. Though the taste was not that bad as well. The service was good, and they also had a huge seating. Overall, it was an okay experience.

Tunday Kababi of Lucknow wah just lajawab mouthwatering dishes. Galawati kabab are so delicious. Chicken Biryani and Mutton Korma are also very tasty. Tunday is famous all over India for its Gulawati Kababs. Non vegetarians most favoured choice in Lucknow.

Taste ... Masha allah....
Plz plz plzz try the Mutton Galaoti Kabab with the Mughlai paratha....
The Awadh Chicken Biryani was also too good ...

Chicken seekh kabab was a little dry and could have been better....

Overall experience.... Five Star

Tunday Kababi is A Famous Name among Travellers & Food Lovers visiting the Historic city of Lucknow.
I visited the place with very High expectations to Eat Delicious Tunday Kabab & Awadhi Biryani.
As a Food Lover I have visited Different Eateries in Kolkata & other Places in India.
Especially when Kolkata Biryani is a Modified Awadhi Biryani, My Expectations in this place was very High.
I would like to share Details of my Experience:
Pros:
1. Food was Good in Taste in General.
2. Though there was a rush in the Restaurant the service boy served Food very much fast & Food was Hot .
Cons:
1. Tunday Kabab was Good, but it is overrated.
People may have different opinions.
But I think Taste was Good not Great.
2. Awadhi Biryani was also Good in Taste, but not Great as it is praised in General.
3. Biryani served in very small plates like a College Canteen.
4. Mutton needed to be Cooked a little bit more.

Mouth-Melting Magic ‚Äì A Lucknow Legend!

If there‚Äôs one place in Lucknow that lives up to the hype, it‚Äôs Tunday Kababi in Aminabad. The kebabs literally melt in your mouth ‚Äî soft, flavorful, and so perfectly spiced that it‚Äôs hard to put the experience into words. You have to try it yourself to believe it!

The service is quick, and the menu is full of delicious Mughlai options. But trust me, once you taste the kebabs, you won‚Äôt stop at just one plate. They‚Äôre that addictive!

I‚Äôve completely fallen in love with Tunday Kababi. I‚Äôm definitely going back to try more from their menu. This place is a must-visit ‚Äî in fact, it should be your very first stop the moment you land in Lucknow.

Highly recommended to all food lovers. You simply can‚Äôt say you‚Äôve tasted Lucknow if you haven‚Äôt been to Tunday Kababi!

placeMetadata.name: Lucknow Mahotsav Sthal

sources.snippet: Walking through parts of Lucknow is like stepping back in time minus all the modern-day technology we're so used to seeing today. Palaces were commonplace in those days; take note when you see the Kaiserbagh Palace Complex and Dilkusha Kothi during your visit. Both landmarks are uniquely designed yet share a common theme of meticulous craftsmanship that locals are very proud of.
sources.shortName: A Journey through Palaces and Kebabs

placeMetadata.description: Exhibition center offering a range of professional services as well as 200 commercial stalls.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Lucknow Mahotsav Sthal is an exhibition center that hosts the annual Lucknow Mahotsav, a 10-day festival showcasing the art and culture of Uttar Pradesh, particularly Lucknawi Tehzeeb. The event features traditional dramas, colorful processions, Kathak dance performances from the famous Lucknow Gharana, as well as Sitaar, Sarangi and Tabla recitals.
placeMetadata.address: Smriti Upvan, Kanshiram, Jalvayu Vihar, Ashiyana, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226012, India

reviews.reviewText: It is more suitable for small and medium enterprises to save their products. It is also a good place for elders, families and children to roam around. For the public, there is a hotel for eating and a good place for swinging.

Overall a good experience, first you have to buy a 40 ‚Çπticket for entry.
Everything was good but the price of everything from the swing or rides to the tea was found to be more than its original price, for example a swing was 120 ‚Çπfor 5-7 minutes, while the price of food items was also 20-30‚Çπ more. The rest of the household and kitchen items can be found at a very good price if you know how to bargain.
Take care of your valuables like phones and jewellery or leave them at home. Lastly, since online transactions are not available everywhere, it is also mandatory to bring cash.

I felt mahotsav this year was bit smaller as compared to previous ones. not all the stalls were in display but still a good place to visit with family and friends. Kids are gonna love it.
One can find almost all the daily need items starting from utensils, beauty accessories, home decor items , carpets, bedsheets etc.

This place is a  hidden gem! I visited Lucknow Mahotsav Sthal on 25 November and it was an unforgettable experience. I was greeted by the vibrant stalls selling handicrafts, carpets, and so much more. It felt like a mini-India, with representatives from almost every state showcasing their unique culture.

I'm a sucker for swings, and the ones here were amazing - I felt like a kid again! The food stalls were also a delight, with the aroma of kebabs and biryani wafting through the air.

What I loved most was the tribute to the nawabs and Atal Vihari Vajpayee - it's clear that Lucknow is proud of its heritage. And the ghazal performances in the evening? Mesmerizing! This place is also good for morning walks.

If you're looking for a taste of India's diversity and richness, Lucknow Mahotsav Sthal is a must-visit. Don't miss it, folks!

Lucknow Mohatsav Sthal is a great place to spend some time outdoors and get some exercise. This huge park is spread over a few acres and is well planned with walking and jogging tracks, plenty of benches for sitting, greenery all over, and even a few peacocks!
I visit this park daily for morning walks, and one round of the park is about 3300 steps. It's the perfect place for morning and evening walks, exercise, and you can even play badminton too.

What I love about this park is the peaceful atmosphere and the feeling of being surrounded by nature. The park is well-maintained, and the greenery is a treat for the eyes. The peacocks add to the charm of the place, and it's always a joy to see them strutting around.

One thing that could be improved is the availability of drinking water facilities. While there are a few water fountains, they are not enough for the size of the park.

Overall, Lucknow Mohatsav Sthal is a wonderful place to spend some time outdoors and get some exercise. With its well-planned tracks, greenery, and peacocks, it's definitely worth a visit. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a peaceful and refreshing break from the city's hustle and bustle. Therefore, I would give it a four-star rating.

Lucknow Mahotsava was so great this time and special as it was dedicated to the memory of former P.M. Atal Behari Vajpayee ji.What people loved most was Atal Village, a model of village built with care to introduce youngsters who had never been to a Village.It had various stalls too selling village products plus it was the venue for Bal Mahotsava ,whose various programs entertained visitors in the afternoon.The main Mahotsava Hall had Youth Mahotsava programs in the day and cultural programs in the evening. Marijuana had varied shops selling crockery, clothes and carved wood and stone stuff, both handicrafts and machine made. Food Court saw people savouring wide variety of foods like Rajasthani cuisine,Punjabi Cuisine and of course Nawabi Lucknow cuisine.Rajasthani dance troupe entertained as well as a family showing puppet show. A gallery was solely dedicated to the memory of Atal ji in pictures and video. R.B.I. stall saw many visitors for exchanging currency.Various exciting Joyrides were the next popular destination for visitors.Stalls and attractions were so many that you needed at least two full days. Kashmiri stalls also drew lots of crowds for warm stoles, shawls etc.  and also for genuine dry fruits from the valley. Management and security was really good and cleanliness was great too, wheelchairs were available too. People had a wonderful time with family here and eventually it was extended by The Governor till this Sunday. On Sunday it was the day of cheap deals at throwaway prices and crowd surge was excellent and stall owners sold a lot and were happy too to bid adieu to the Lucknow Mahotsava until next year.

Lucknow Mahotsav Sthal, a vast ground, hosts the grand Lucknow Mahotsav, offering a spacious and engaging venue. This expansive setting accommodates diverse activities and fairs, ensuring a comfortable and immersive experience for attendees. Well-maintained and inviting, the grounds contribute to the event's grandeur, creating a seamless and enjoyable environment. Lucknow Mahotsav usually hosted in month of December or early January

sources.snippet: Built by Nawab Wajid Ali Shah, Safed Baradari is a white marbled palace originally constructed as the Nawab's "Palace of Mourning". The building was initially called Qasr-ul-Aza and was later used by the British to hold court for petition.
sources.shortName: 18 Top Historical Places in Lucknow

placeMetadata.description: This white marble palace built in 1854 as a place of mourning now hosts wedding celebrations.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Safed Baradari, a white marble palace constructed in 1854 by Wajid Ali Shah, originally served as an imambara for Ashura mourning. It was a place where renowned vocalists performed lamentations and mournful songs. Today, it hosts weddings, formal ceremonies, and various performances while still preserving its historical significance.

If you're vising the venue till last week of November you'll experience this multi culture exhibition and won't regret.

Visit if you've a special place for culture, art craft and tradition of India.

Located in Qaiserbagh, Lucknow, near other historic spots like Chattar Manzil and the Begum Hazrat Mahal Park.

Easily reachable by auto, cab, or rickshaw from Hazratganj or Charbagh Railway Station.

Ample space outside, but no dedicated parking area for visitors.

---

üï∞Ô∏è 2. Timings & Entry

Open roughly from 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM, though hours may vary during events.

Entry Fee: ‚Çπ20 for Indian nationals, higher for foreign tourists.

Tickets are often available at the gate; no advance booking required for casual visits.

---

üïå 3. Architecture & Design

A beautiful white-marble structure built in 1854 by Nawab Wajid Ali Shah.

Traditional Baradari-style architecture with 12 arched doorways, marble flooring, and fine stucco detailing.

A large central hall filled with natural light, chandeliers, and historical statues.

---

üîç 4. Historical Significance

Originally used as a mourning hall during Muharram.

Later served as a petition court under British rule.

Also associated with freedom fighters during the 1857 rebellion.

Still maintained by the British India Association of Oudh (Taluqdar community).

---

üß≠ 5. Basement Crypt (Tehkhana)

A hidden underground chamber (rarely open) that once held religious items and water features.

Sometimes accessible during special festivals or heritage walks like the Sanatkada Festival.

Not always open‚Äîcheck in advance or ask the caretaker.

---

üéâ 6. Events & Cultural Use

Currently used for exhibitions, weddings, official banquets, and cultural events.

Hosts annual festivals like Sanatkada, classical concerts, and heritage exhibitions.

Occasionally featured in Bollywood films (Umrao Jaan, Tanu Weds Manu).

---

üåø 7. Ambience & Photography

Very peaceful and serene environment, especially in the morning hours.

Great for photography, especially lovers of architecture and history.

Marble backdrop and symmetry make it ideal for portraits and cultural shoots.

---

üöª 8. Facilities & Maintenance

Basic toilet facilities available during events.

No on-site caf√© or food stall, but eateries are nearby.

The structure is under ASI care, and conservation efforts are ongoing.

Signage and visitor guides are limited, but locals may help with basic history.

---

‚úÖ 9. Pros

‚úÖ Unique white-marble heritage building

‚úÖ Rich history with cultural significance

‚úÖ Calm surroundings in central Lucknow

‚úÖ Great for photography, culture, and events

‚úÖ Occasionally opens its secret underground crypt

---

‚ö†Ô∏è 10. Cons

‚ùå No guided tours or detailed information boards

‚ùå Crypt is not always open to the public

‚ùå Can be closed during private events without notice

‚ùå Limited visitor facilities (e.g., parking, food stalls)

Charbagh Railway Station is a magnificent architectural marvel that blends Mughal, Awadhi and Rajput styles. It is one of the largest and busiest railway stations in India, serving as a hub for both Northern and North-Eastern railways. The station has nine platforms, a spacious garden, a clock tower, and a grand entrance. The station building was constructed in 1926 and has a palatial appearance with domes, minarets, arches and verandas. The station is also well-connected with the Lucknow Metro, which makes it easy to reach the airport and other parts of the city. The station is located in the historical area of Charbagh, which means four gardens. It is close to many attractions such as Bara Imambara, Chota Imambara, British Residency, Lucknow Zoo and Ambedkar Park. The station is also known for its cleanliness, security and amenities such as WiFi, parking, cloak room, restaurants and retiring rooms. Charbagh Railway Station is a must-visit place for anyone who wants to experience the culture and heritage of Lucknow.
Paid A.C not working properly

harbagh Railway Station is one of the busiest railway stations in India and serves as a major transportation hub for northern India. The station is located in the heart of the city and is well-connected to various parts of the city by public transport, such as buses, taxis, and auto-rickshaws.

The station has several platforms and handles a large number of passenger trains, including long-distance trains and local trains. It is a junction station, connecting several important railway lines, including the Delhi-Kanpur line, the Lucknow-Moradabad line, and the Lucknow-Sultanpur line.

Charbagh Railway Station has several amenities for passengers, including waiting halls, restrooms, restaurants, and shops selling books, magazines, and souvenirs. The station also has facilities like luggage storage, ATM machines, and currency exchange counters.

The station has undergone several renovations and modernization efforts in recent years, including the construction of new platforms and the installation of modern equipment and facilities to improve the passenger experience. The station has also been made more accessible to people with disabilities, with the installation of ramps and other accessibility features.

sources.snippet: Rumi Darwaza is a captivating pre-wedding shoot location in Lucknow that offers a perfect unite of historical charm and architectural glory. This iconic gateway, also known as the ‚ÄúTurkish Gate,‚Äù is renowned for its stunning Mughal architecture and design, making it a beautiful backdrop for your pre-wedding shoot in Lucknow. sources.snippet: When you want to witness the grandeur of the Awadhi style of architecture, make your way to the Rumi Darwaza, an imposing gateway located between Bara Imambara and Chota Imambara. This gateway built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula is about 60-feet tall and is generally used as the logo for Lucknow city. Since the gate is modeled after the Sublime Porte in Istanbul, it is sometimes referred to as the Turkish Gate.
sources.shortName: Top 25 Places To Visit In Lucknow (2024): Entry Fee, Timings

sources.snippet: A sixty feet tall memorabilia of the grandeur of Awadhi architecture, Rumi Darwaza in the old city is one of the signature places to visit in Lucknow. Located in the middle of Bara Imambara and Chota Imambara, this imposing gateway was built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula after a famine struck North India. In exchange for daily meals, the Awadhi workers built the great Rumi Darwaza for the Nawab.

sources.snippet: The famous Rumi Darwaza entrance in Lucknow stands tall as a symbol of the city‚Äôs magnificent architecture. Rumi Darwaza, also known as the Turkish Gate, gets its inspiration from the historic entry to Constantinople (Istanbul).

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rumi Darwaza is a significant historical landmark in Lucknow, standing at 60 feet tall and serving as an emblem of the city. Built in 1784, it showcases intricate Awadhi-style architecture and is associated with the flourishing era of Asaf-ud-Dawlah, known for his patronage of arts and culture. The gateway offers a stunning view and serves as a popular backdrop for nighttime photography due to its brilliant illumination.
placeMetadata.address: 17/11 Hussainabad Road, Lajpat Nagar Colony, Lajpat Nagar, Machchhi Bhavan, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226003, India

reviews.reviewText:
Rumi Darwaza, one of Lucknow‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, stands as a majestic symbol of the city‚Äôs rich Nawabi heritage and architectural brilliance. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula during a period of severe famine, the structure not only provided employment to thousands but also left behind a masterpiece that continues to awe visitors centuries later. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúTurkish Gate‚Äù due to its Awadhi architectural style inspired by Turkish design, the Rumi Darwaza rises to a height of 60 feet, with a striking arched gateway and intricately carved floral motifs adorning its surface.

Sadly, in recent years, the monument has undergone a round of repainting rather than proper restoration. The use of modern paints, rather than historically accurate conservation techniques, has slightly dulled its original charm. Yet, even this cosmetic intervention hasn‚Äôt managed to mask its beauty. The gateway still exudes elegance and grandeur.

What makes Rumi Darwaza even more intriguing is its resemblance to the shape of a traditional necklace ‚Äî and to those familiar with Lucknow‚Äôs textile artistry, it uncannily echoes the layout of a chikan kurta design. It‚Äôs a bridge between architecture and culture, the physical and the artistic. Despite changes over time, Rumi Darwaza continues to be a proud emblem of Lucknow‚Äôs past and present.

Recently Visiting Rumi Darwaza in Lucknow is an awesome old Awadhi architecture. The marvelous carvings and grand design make it a beautiful sight. It resemble to the shape of a traditional necklace and pendant. It's considered one of the proud emblem and most photogenic spots of Lucknow. If you are in Lucknow please don‚Äôt miss here to take a picture. Visit this place in early hours for good pictures and avoid crowd. After Delhi and Agra I found architecturally beautiful city is Lucknow. As the name suggests itself and some people called it the Turkish Gate. Must visit.

1.Architectural Beauty:
Visitors often praise the Rumi Darwaza for its grand design and detailed carvings. Many call it a "masterpiece of Awadhi architecture."

2. Perfect for Photography:
Tourists love clicking photos here. It's considered one of the most photogenic spots in Lucknow, especially in the early morning or at sunset.

3. Historical Importance:
Many people appreciate the deep historical value of the gate. They mention it transports you to the era of Nawabs and Mughal influences.

4. Central Location:
Since it‚Äôs located in the heart of Lucknow, it's easy to combine a visit with other nearby attractions like Bada Imambara and Chota Imambara.

5. Mixed Notes on Maintenance:
Some reviewers feel that while the structure itself is stunning, better maintenance (especially cleanliness around the area) could make the experience even better

Rumi Darwaza in Lucknow is a stunning example of Awadhi architecture. The intricate carvings and grand design make it a beautiful sight to behold. The structure's elegance and beauty are captivating, making it a must-visit spot for anyone who appreciates architectural marvels and photography opportunities. Very impressive.

Lucknow has its own legacy and Rumi darwaja is itself dignity from centuries.
Nawabo ka shahar is full of heritage sites and Rumi darwaja is witness of Nawabi prestige. Made in 1784, it's structure is stands well maintained and attract tourists all around the world.

Rumi Darwaza is beautiful intricate historical monument. If you look at it closely you‚Äôll find details that depicts Lucknow‚Äôs handicrafts and culture. There is no ticket or entry fee, you can take a stop here while driving through the old city, admire it‚Äôs beauty and take a few pictures while you are at it üòÑ

Visited Rumi Darwaza in August 2025 and was struck by its majestic design. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula, it's a fine example of Awadhi architecture and once marked the gateway to the city. Mr Ikhlaq and his friends shared the historical significance, adding depth to the experience. The view during sunset was beautiful and peaceful, and the energy around the place was vibrant. A must-visit spot that reflects the royal past of Lucknow.

Janeshwar Mishra Park, located in Lucknow's Gomti Nagar, is one of Asia's largest urban parks, spanning approximately 376 acres.  Established in memory of the late politician Janeshwar Mishra, the park offers a multitude of features and attractions. Here are five notable aspects:

1. Extensive Green Spaces: The park boasts vast expanses of lush lawns and diverse flora, providing visitors with a serene environment ideal for relaxation and picnics.

2. Recreational Facilities: Designed with fitness enthusiasts in mind, the park includes well-maintained jogging and cycling tracks, encouraging outdoor activities and promoting a healthy lifestyle.

3. Scenic Water Bodies: Central to the park is a picturesque man-made lake, offering opportunities for boating and enhancing the park's aesthetic appeal.

4. Cultural and Entertainment Events: The park features an auditorium that hosts various cultural events and musical performances, enriching the cultural fabric of the community.

5. Eco-Friendly Initiatives: Emphasizing sustainability, the park incorporates eco-friendly practices such as solar power utilization and rainwater harvesting, serving as a model for environmental conservation.

These features collectively make Janeshwar Mishra Park a prominent recreational destination, catering to a wide array of interests and promoting environmental awareness.

Visited Janeshwar Mishra Park‚Äîsuch a lovely, sprawling green space perfect for a day out. The Jurassic World section is a big hit with kids, keeping them entertained. People really shouldn‚Äôt litter or pollute this beautiful park; let‚Äôs keep it clean so everyone can enjoy it.

Watercoolers and various shops for juice and drinks and snacks are available in the park

placeMetadata.name: Bara Imambara

sources.snippet: Counted among the top historical places in Lucknow, Bara Imambara aka Asafi Imambara is a historical monument that dates back to 1784. Built by Asaf-ud-Daula, one of the renowned Nawabs of Awadh, the complex comprises a large mosque (Asfi Mosque), a labyrinth (the Bhul Bhulaiya), and a stepwell with running water (Shahi Baoli). The structure boasts of two large gateways that will lead you to the central hall, which is touted to be the largest vaulted chamber in the world.

sources.snippet: Synonymous with historical places to visit in Lucknow, Bara Imambara or Asafi Imambara was built in 1784 by Asaf-ud-Daula, a renowned Nawab of Awadh. The monument hosts a large mosque called the Asfi Mosque, a maze called the Bhool Bhulaiya and a royal stepwell with water called the Shahi Baoli. Historical mugal palace and worship place at Lucknow. The Bhool Bhulaiya in Bara Imambara in Lucknow is a labyrinth of interconnected tunnels, with each path branching into many others and only one leads to the exit. It is a must visit as the exiting the labyrinth will be challenging and time consuming. Place is maintained well and organised crowd management by the authorities are appreciative.

A place with picture worthy views but  mismanaged by authorities

I was born in Lucknow, and I am a local.
Today I visited the Imambara 3rd time in my life, last visit was in 2008 and these are the below things I observed.
1. There is no  baggage or security check. This place is piece of cake for any one with bad intentions or wants to cause havoc.
2. Ticket price for adults is INR 50 which is ok but for visiting the roof area or the bhool bhulaiyaa, a guide has to be hired which will cost minimum INR 100.
3. Before entering the Imambara or the bhool bhulaiya everyone must deposit his/her shoes outside the inner Imambara entrance and the men at the deposit counter will say "jo dena ho dede" which means the price for security deposit is not fixed and they mostly keep shoes and slippers in open. If there is rain the shoes can get wet. There is no proper cloak room.
4. Since taking guide is mandatory for bhool bhulaiya we had to forcefully do so and the guide will take you and show you the various holy things kept in Imambara. The guide that we got was named Raja Hindustani and his diction was not at all clear. He took us on the narrow paths made of the dome of the Imambara without footwear and there was no lights and the floor is broken at places and can cause cuts and bruises. The maintenance of this place is worst I have ever experienced. I will suggest not to take small kids here and that too on a weekend. My 4 year daughter was feeling scared and also this place is not for claustrophobic people.
5. Our guide passed a comment too on my wife which she opposed and yelled at him after which our group consisting of 40 people praised and clapped for my wife as she vented out at the guide who all the group members were forced to follow even though his way of explaining things or tackling crowd was pathetic. Many women came and told my wife " good you shouted at him " as all of the people were frustrated but not speaking up against the unruly behaviour of the guide.
6. Since the roof is all stones and everywhere it is hard and uneven , walking on it for kids is very hard and chances of getting hurt are high.
7. Nevertheless it is a picturesque place and if you hire a proper guide who takes more money your experience can be better but the forced guide system and no light being in the narrow pathways is risky for women.
The forced guide will charge INR 150 for complete tour.
8. Now my next visit maybe after next 15 16 years and if given a chance may not visit at all.
I love Lucknow for the food and culture but at present taking some outsider to this place may only cause you embarrassment. They should install lights in dark pathways and remove the mandate of removing shoes on the roof of the building as it causes huge discomfort to tourists. The renovation from outside makes the building look pretty.

Bada Imambara, the "Pride of Lucknow" is a majestic architectural masterpiece, built by the aristocratic Nawabs many centuries ago. I got the opportunity to visit this place and its entry ticket gives you access to visit other nearby iconic destinations too, like Chota Imambara, Shahi Bauli, Bhool Bhulaiya etc. In the Bada Imambara you are required to deposit your shoes in the shoe counter before entering its many impressive sections. One important point to note is that they don't allow unmarried couples to enter Bhool Bhulaiya without hiring a guide.
Overall, it's a spectacular place to visit in Lucknow!üí´

Bada Imambada in Lucknow is one of the city‚Äôs most iconic monuments and a must-visit for history and architecture lovers. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula, this grand complex reflects the elegance of Mughal and Awadhi architecture, constructed without the use of wood or iron.

The highlight of the monument is the Bhulbhulaiya (labyrinth) ‚Äì a fascinating maze of narrow passages, countless identical doorways, and hidden staircases. Exploring it is both exciting and slightly mysterious, and it‚Äôs easy to lose your way without a guide. Hiring a local guide is strongly recommended, as they not only help you navigate the maze but also share interesting historical stories about the Imambada.

Another marvel is the central arched hall, one of the largest in the world without any supporting beams. Standing inside feels majestic and showcases the genius of 18th-century engineering. The complex also includes the Asfi Mosque and the Shahi Baoli (stepwell), each worth visiting for their design and historical significance.

The site is generally well maintained, with reasonable entry fees, and combined tickets give access to all attractions inside. Weekends and holidays can be crowded, so mornings are the best time to visit. Parking is available outside, and after exploring, you can enjoy authentic Lucknowi food at nearby eateries.

Overall, Bara Imambada along with the famous Bhulbhulaiya is an unforgettable experience ‚Äì a mix of history, culture, and architectural brilliance. A true jewel of Lucknow!

Though we were not allowed in due to a religious event there, the building frok outside looked beautiful. However, the entrance to it, the road leading to it, the adjoining places of interest were extremely dirty and filthy with no maintenance done for years it seems. Such great heritage is totally neglected.

Bara Imambara is not just an architectural masterpiece but also a symbol of Lucknow's historical and cultural tapestry. Whether you're a history enthusiast architecture aficionado or a curious traveler a visit to this monument promises a memorable experience.

It's renowned for its magnificent architecture, including one of the world's largest unsupported vaulted halls. The most famous feature is the "Bhulbhulaiya," a dense, confusing labyrinth on the upper floor. The complex also houses the Asafi Mosque and a stepwell, offering a complete glimpse into Awadhi art and engineering. It's a key landmark that showcases the city's rich cultural heritage. I recommend if you are in lucknow you must visit this marvel

Lohia Park known as Dr Ram Manohar Lohia Park has an impressive 76 acres. It boast of expansive lawns, vibrant flowers, serene water features, and a rich tapestry of flora and fauna. You can also spot different species of birds here.

As you step through one of the park‚Äôs four gates, a towering statue of Dr. Ram Manohar Lohia stands, accompanied by a board detailing his life and invaluable contributions.

There is many tracks for you to chose from. You can either go for a run, walk or simply spend some time with friends and families together.

There is also a child's playground and an excercise activity equipment for adults.

We saw a handful of people running while others walking to excercise their cardio.

Near Gate 1 on the right there is a coffee kiosk with some breakfast bread if you want to sit and enjoy some cuppa.

This place can become a healthy ritual or habbit for your well-being.

I found 3 toilet blocks but there could be more for your convenience.

Sikandar Bagh is a historic garden complex located in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, noted for its rich cultural significance and architectural grandeur. It was built in the mid-19th century by Nawab Wajid Ali Shah, the last Nawab of Awadh, as a summer residence and a tribute to his beloved wife, Sikandar Mahal Begum. The garden‚Äôs name literally means "Garden of Sikandar," and it was intended as a private retreat and a cultural hub for the Nawab‚Äôs court.

Spanning approximately four and a half acres, Sikandar Bagh was designed as a fortified enclosure with high walls made from Lakhauri bricks, featuring intricate plaster moldings. Initially, the complex included a summer palace, a mosque, and a wooden pavilion intended for cultural performances such as Ras-Lila (a traditional dramatic enactment of Krishna‚Äôs life), Kathak dance recitals, music concerts, and poetic gatherings. The garden was renowned for its serene beauty, shaded by tall trees and dotted with fountains, offering a peaceful environment for relaxation and artistic expression.

Architecturally, Sikandar Bagh is an exceptional blend of Indian, Persian, European, and Chinese styles. The gateway that still stands today is a splendid example, adorned with intricate frescoes that resemble Lucknow‚Äôs famous Chikan embroidery. The decorations on the walls and domes include floral motifs and peacock iconography, reflecting a cultural fusion that embodied the Nawabi era's cosmopolitan tastes. The gateway's arches, pediments, chhatris (domed pavilions), and pillars exhibit this blend beautifully, echoing the artistic sophistication of the time.

However, the serene ambiance of Sikandar Bagh was dramatically shattered in 1857 during the Indian Rebellion (also known as the First War of Independence). Sikandar Bagh became a stronghold for Indian sepoys opposing British colonial rule. The fortress-like garden witnessed fierce battles in November 1857 when British forces under Sir Colin Campbell launched a brutal assault to reclaim control. Over 2,000 sepoy freedom fighters were killed during this assault, and the site became infamous for the slaughter that ensued within its walls. The walls still bear the scars of this violent conflict, and skeletal remains were photographed by early war correspondents, marking Sikandar Bagh as a site of immense historical trauma.

Following the rebellion, the British used the site for their military purposes briefly before it was left largely in ruins. Today, Sikandar Bagh stands as a poignant monument, embodying both the artistic heritage of the Nawabs and the brutal realities of colonial conquest. The garden has been preserved by the Archaeological Survey of India and is now part of the National Botanical Research Institute campus.

Visitors today can admire the surviving gateway, which serves as a vivid reminder of Lucknow‚Äôs rich past, from its cultural zenith under Nawabi patronage to its central role in the struggle against colonial rule. The garden itself remains a tranquil retreat in the midst of a bustling city, with its shaded area providing a quiet escape for morning walkers, families, and history enthusiasts.
Sikandar Bagh is a magnificent cultural and historical landmark of Lucknow. Built as a garden palace by Nawab Wajid Ali Shah in honor of his wife, it reflects a unique confluence of architectural styles and was once a vibrant space for the performing arts. It became a symbol of resistance during the 1857 revolt, witnessing intense fighting and bloodshed. Today, preserved as a heritage site, it stands as a solemn tribute to both the artistic heritage and the sacrifices of those who fought for India‚Äôs freedom.

Having lived in Lucknow all my life, I had visited The Residency as a child but never truly explored it. Recently, I finally took the time to revisit this historic gem ‚Äî and I‚Äôm so glad I did.

The moment you step inside, you‚Äôre transported to a time that shaped India‚Äôs history. The ruins, still marked with bullet holes and cannon fire, silently narrate the intensity of the 1857 revolt. Each structure within the complex ‚Äî from the Baillie Guard Gate and Treasury to the church ruins and underground chambers ‚Äî holds a haunting charm.

Walking through the wide lawns and shaded pathways, I spent time at the museum, the graveyard, and the many crumbling buildings that once formed the heart of British residency life. The view from the top of some of the structures is breathtaking, and the atmosphere is both peaceful and reflective.

It‚Äôs not just a monument, it‚Äôs a memory ‚Äî of resilience, history, and a city that has seen so much. If you‚Äôre in Lucknow, The Residency deserves your time and attention.

Nestled near the iconic Chota Imambara, this unfinished four-storey tower ‚Äî originally intended to be a seven-storey marvel ‚Äî stands as a quiet testament to Nawabi-era ambition and architectural beauty.

With its unique blend of Mughal and Italian influences, Satkhanda is both historically intriguing and visually stunning. Though not as widely known as other monuments in the city, it‚Äôs a place that truly rewards those who seek it out.

Located in the historic Hussainabad area of Lucknow, Satkhanda is a unique and intriguing monument. Situated near other popular landmarks like the Chota Imambara, it stands as a testament to the city's rich architectural past and the vision of its rulers.
‚ÄãThe word "Satkhanda" literally means "seven-storied," a name that hints at its unfulfilled ambition. It was commissioned by Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah to be a magnificent seven story watchtower, but its construction was tragically halted after his untimely death. This abrupt ending has made it a symbol of both ambition and a touch of melancholy.
‚ÄãArchitecturally, the tower is a fascinating blend of Mughal, Greek, and French styles. Made of red bricks, its most distinctive feature is its tapering design, where each of the four completed stories is smaller than the one below it. This gives it an appearance reminiscent of the famous Leaning Tower of Pisa.
‚ÄãToday, Satkhanda remains an unfinished masterpiece. While it may not have reached its intended height, its unique story and striking design make it a popular spot for visitors and photographers. It stands as a powerful reminder of Lucknow's regal history and the captivating tales that lie behind its heritage structures.

Satkhanda in Lucknow is a must-visit historical landmark that beautifully showcases the city's rich cultural heritage. Located near the Bara Imambara, this incomplete seven-story tower offers a glimpse into the past with its architectural elegance and intriguing history.

The tower was built during the reign of Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula in the 18th century but was never fully completed, which adds an air of mystery to its presence. The structure is a fine example of Mughal and Awadhi architecture, with intricate carvings and detailed work that reflect the artistic excellence of that era.

While the tower may not offer a panoramic view from its top due to its unfinished state, the view from the lower levels is still impressive. The location is relatively quiet, making it a good spot for those who enjoy a peaceful walk while soaking in the local history.

What makes Satkhanda stand out is its historical significance. It was once intended to rival other monumental structures in the region, and it tells a unique story of ambition and unfinished dreams. Visitors can enjoy the peaceful surroundings and learn more about Lucknow's Nawabi era and its grandeur.

Overall, Satkhanda is an interesting and charming spot for history buffs, architecture lovers, and anyone keen on exploring the lesser-known facets of Lucknow‚Äôs history.

Old signs of vandalism and brainless love scribbles exist as a reminder that a lot of people don't value Heritage.

Gripes apart, this is a must visit and barely a 10 mins ride from City centre. This hunting lodge cum Summer retreat for the nawabs and British residents alike would have been a vibrant place in the early 19th century. Hopefully the tourism development corporation would better publicize this place and allot a decent budget for better upkeep and maintenance.

Entry is free from sunrise till sunset but you may find the main gate locked till 10 am. Even otherwise, the gate was perplexingly locked with a loose chain which makes visitors squeeze through the gates. Parking is amply available on site for two and four wheelers.

The Hussainabad Clock Tower is truly a beautiful landmark in Lucknow. The architecture is stunning, with intricate details that make it stand out, especially when seen up close. In the resplendent city of Lucknow, a towering marvel of modernity pierces the sky ‚Äì the illustrious Clock Tower, a masterpiece of Moorish design, erstwhile believed to be the largest in the Indian subcontinent. This magnificent edifice, a symphony of stone and steel, is illuminated by a dazzling array of lamps, its beauty further enhanced by the melodic chime of five bells, whose sweet peals echo through the air. Standing tall at 221 feet, this grandiose structure is an exemplar of traditional British architecture, rivaling the iconic Big Ben of London in both splendor and majesty. Its colossal wheels, a marvel of engineering, surpass even those of its London counterpart.

Conceived by the visionary architect of those times- Richard Roskell Bayne, this monumental clock tower was erected at a cost of two lakhs, funded by the benevolent Trustees of the Husainabad Endowment, who wisely invested the legacy of thirty-six lakhs of rupees bequeathed by the illustrious Muhammad Ali Shah, third King of Oudh. Bayne‚Äôs masterpiece, a testament to his ingenuity, boasts a intricate machinery comprising wrought-iron sides, gun-metal wheels, and hardened steel pinions, precision-crafted to ensure unwavering accuracy.

This majestic timepiece, a true marvel of modern science, stands as a shining beacon, a testament to the confluence of art and engineering. Its grandeur is a reflection of Bayne‚Äôs prolific career, which spanned the construction of bridges, train stations, and bungalows, as well as monumental buildings such as the East India Railway Office, New Market in Kolkata, and Oak Grove School in Mussoorie. His legacy extends to the Thornhill and Mayne Memorial Library and Mayo Memorial in Allahabad, a testament to his enduring impact on India‚Äôs architectural landscape.

Husainabad Clock Tower is a stunning heritage landmark and the tallest clock tower in India. The architecture is remarkable, especially when lit up in the evening. It‚Äôs a peaceful, clean, and well-kept heritage site, perfect for history lovers, photographers, or anyone wanting a glimpse of Lucknow‚Äôs royal past. Highly recommended if you‚Äôre visiting the city!

The tower is located near other heritage sites like the Rumi Darwaza and Husainabad Imambara, making it an integral part of Lucknow‚Äôs cultural and architectural landscape.

Gomti Riverfront and 1090 Chauraha together represent two unique yet complementary sides of Lucknow‚Äôs modern urban charm‚Äîone offers calm and natural beauty, while the other radiates youthful energy and vibrancy.

Gomti Riverfront is a peaceful escape in the heart of the city. Lined with beautifully landscaped gardens, wide jogging paths, musical fountains, and scenic views of the river, it‚Äôs perfect for morning walks, evening strolls, yoga, and quiet reflection. The entire area is very clean, well-lit, and carefully maintained, making it a safe and welcoming environment for families, children, fitness lovers, and photographers. Whether you‚Äôre visiting solo or with loved ones, the tranquil atmosphere and cool river breeze offer a refreshing break from the chaos of daily life.

Just a few minutes away lies 1090 Chauraha‚Äîa completely different but equally fascinating urban hotspot. Known not only for its connection with the UP Women Power Line, it has evolved into a youth magnet. In the evenings, it comes alive with college students, local skaters, joggers, influencers filming content, and people simply catching up over tea and street snacks. Despite being a public space, it feels secure and organized. The open layout, decorative lighting, and wide sidewalks make it perfect for casual hangouts, open-air discussions, or simply enjoying the street buzz.

Together, Gomti Riverfront and 1090 Chauraha reflect the soul of a new, progressive Lucknow‚Äîone side offers inner peace, while the other celebrates public energy. Both are must-visits for anyone looking to experience the contrasting yet connected moods of the city.

Begum Hazrat Mahal Park in Lucknow is more than just a green space; it's a poignant reminder of a significant figure in India's struggle for independence. Named after the valiant Begum Hazrat Mahal, the wife of Nawab Wajid Ali Shah, who played a key role in the 1857 uprising, the park offers a tranquil escape with a touch of history.
The park's well-maintained lawns and pathways invite leisurely strolls, making it a popular spot for morning and evening walks. The lush greenery provides a refreshing contrast to the city's bustle, offering a serene environment for relaxation and reflection. You'll often find families enjoying picnics, children playing, and elderly residents engaging in their daily routines, creating a vibrant yet peaceful atmosphere.
While the park's landscaping is pleasant, the true draw lies in its historical significance. A memorial structure dedicated to Begum Hazrat Mahal stands within the park, serving as a tribute to her courage and leadership. Though some visitors mention that the fountains are not always operational, the overall ambiance and the park's connection to a pivotal moment in Indian history make it a worthwhile visit.
Located centrally, Begum Hazrat Mahal Park is easily accessible. It's a place where one can connect with the past while enjoying a moment of tranquility in the present. Whether you're a history enthusiast or simply seeking a peaceful retreat in Lucknow, this park offers a meaningful and refreshing experience.

The Park was Established in 1962, and bears her name to honour her contributions to India's struggle for freedom. Today, it stands as a source of pride and a constant reminder of the sacrifices made by countless individuals during that terrifying period.

Covering an expanse of approximately 112 acres, Begum Hazrat Mahal Park offers visitors a tranquil and picturesque retreat. As one enters the Park, they are greeted by meticulously manicured gardens adorned with vibrant flowerbeds, sprawling lawns, and majestic trees providing refreshing shade.

The Park's design beautifully fuses Mughal and modern architectural elements, creating a harmonious blend of tradition and contemporary aesthetics.

At the heart of Begum Hazrat Mahal Park stands a grand monument dedicated to the memory of the courageous queen herself. This intricately designed marble structure is adorned with ornamental motifs and inscriptions celebrating her courageous endeavours. Serving as a symbol of resistance, it stands tall, honouring the sacrifices made by countless freedom fighters.

Within the Park, a museum houses various artefacts and memorabilia from the Indian Rebellion of 1857. Visitors can explore historical exhibits, including photographs, weaponry, documents, and personal belongings associated with prominent uprising figures. The museum offers a captivating glimpse into the past, enlightening visitors about the historical context and the arduous struggle for independence.

The gorgeous pathways entice visitors to take strolls, allowing them to soak in the serenity of the surroundings. Thoughtfully placed benches offer peaceful spots for relaxation and reflection. The Park also boasts a small pond embellished with elegant fountains, enhancing its visual appeal while providing a habitat for diverse aquatic flora and fauna.

I go to Begum Hazrat Mahal Park in morning for walking and found it to be a serene and historically rich spot in the heart of the city. Established in 1962, the park honors Begum Hazrat Mahal, a key figure in the 1857 Indian Rebellion against British rule.

The park is well-maintained, featuring lush green lawns, vibrant flowerbeds, and shaded pathways that make it ideal for leisurely walks or quiet reflection. At its center stands a marble memorial adorned with the Coat of Arms of the Awadh royal family, paying tribute to Begum Hazrat Mahal's legacy.

Amenities such as clean drinking water and restrooms are available, enhancing the comfort of visitors. Additionally, the park hosts various cultural events and festivals throughout the year, adding to its appeal.

Entry Fee: The entry fee is INR 5 per person & free entry from 6:00 AM to 8:00 AM

Timings: The park is open daily from 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM.

Overall, Begum Hazrat Mahal Park offers a peaceful retreat amidst Lucknow's bustling environment and stands as a testament to the city's rich historical heritage. It's a must-visit for both history enthusiasts and those seeking a tranquil escape.

A beautiful white-marble structure built in 1854 by Nawab Wajid Ali Shah.

Originally used as a mourning hall during Muharram.

Later served as a petition court under British rule.

Also associated with freedom fighters during the 1857 rebellion.

Still maintained by the British India Association of Oudh (Taluqdar community).

What truly impressed me, however, was the zoo's commitment to animal welfare and conservation. The enclosures are spacious and well-maintained, providing the animals with a safe and healthy environment.

While the zoo is generally well-maintained, there are a few areas where it could improve. For example, some of the signage could be clearer, and the food options could be more varied.
Overall, I would highly recommend the Nawab Wajid Ali Shah Zoo to anyone looking for a fun and educational day out. With its incredible variety of animals, spacious enclosures, and family-friendly atmosphere, it's a must-visit destination for anyone in Lucknow!

Being in Lucknow, you absolutely have to see the Chota Imambara, also known as the "Palace of Lights." It's a collection of buildings that really shows how old and fancy Lucknow is. It is in the old part of the city, near the famous Bara Imambara and Rumi Darwaza. Inside, there's a mosque, a tomb, a clock tower, a garden, and even a pond. The main building, the Imambara itself, is where Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah and his mother are buried. Shia Muslims gather here during Muharram.
Start by seeing the Rumi Darwaza, Clock Tower, and Satkhanda first, as they're outside and free to explore. You can buy a combined ticket from the Bara Imambara ticket counter for just ‚Çπ50, which covers the Bara Imambara (including the Bhool Bhulaiya and Bouli), the Chota Imambara (including the Shahi Hamam), and the Picture Gallery. There are separate fees for cameras.
Each spot has its own special charm, but remember, you can't take photos or videos inside the Imambara building itself. The grounds are beautifully kept, with lovely ponds, ornate gates, stylish lamps, and colorful gardens. It's a place that draws visitors from all over the world to admire its architecture, art, and history.
To really appreciate it, it's a good idea to read up on its history beforehand, or you can hire a guide. Parking is available nearby, and the place is wheelchair accessible. Plan to spend at least an hour exploring. You will not regret it!!

The Chota Imambara, also known as Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak, is a stunning historical monument located in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh. Built in 1838 by Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah, the third Nawab of Awadh, it serves as both a Shia congregation hall and a

mausoleum for the Nawab and his mother.

Architectural Highlights

Palace of Lights: The Imambara is famously referred to as the "Palace of Lights" due to its lavish interior adorned with Belgian chandeliers, intricate glasswork, and ornate calligraphy. Wikipedia

Golden Dome & Minarets: The structure boasts a gilded dome, flanked by several turrets and minarets, exemplifying Indo-Islamic architectural brilliance.

Wikipedia

Twin Taj Mahal Replicas: Within the complex are two miniature replicas of the Taj Mahal, serving as tombs for the Nawab's daughter and her husband. Wikipedia +2

Shehnasheen & Zarih: The main hall houses the Shehnasheen, a platform where the Zarih (a replica of the protective structure over Imam Husain's grave in Karbala) is placed, emphasizing the site's religious significance.

Visitor Reviews

Visitors often describe Chota Imambara as a peaceful and serene site, offering a respite from the city's hustle. The gardens are reminiscent of English country landscapes, enhancing the monument's charm. Tripadvisor

The entry fee is ‚Çπ20 for Indian nationals, and hiring a guide costs around ‚Çπ200, providing insightful historical context during the visit.

Visiting Information

Timings: Open daily from 6:00 AM to 5:00 PM.

Best Time to Visit: Evenings during festivals like Muharram, when the Imambara is illuminated, showcasing its "Palace of Lights" moniker.

Nearby Attractions:

Visited Chota Imambara in August 2025 and it was a peaceful experience, though we reached a little after sunset. It's best to come before it gets dark to fully enjoy the stunning interiors and reflections on the water. Built by Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah in 1838, the structure is beautifully ornate and holds deep cultural value. Mr Ikhlaq and friends guided us here too. Right opposite, there‚Äôs a local food court where you can enjoy Lucknowi biryanis and other tasty snacks. A calm and culturally rich spot worth visiting.

Chota Imambara is a major tourist attraction in Lucknow. This place is a part of the complete "Nawab Circuit" that includes Bada Imambara, Shahi Bauli, Bhool Bhulaiya and Photo Gallery. You can either purchase a combo-ticket for the entire "Nawab Circuit" or buy separate tickets for selective places.
