Jama Masjid¬†Lucknow

Adding a unique charm in the historical significance of the city of Nawabs, is the famous Jama Masjid in Lucknow. Built by Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah Bahadur in the year 1839, Jama Masjid is one of the oldest historical landmarks in Lucknow. Along with being a popular tourist site, it also serves as an important religious centre in Lucknow for the Muslim community. Despite being compared with Jama Masjid of Delhi, this mosque has gained its own popularity because of its unique architectural design. Unlike Delhi's Jama Masjid, this one is built of Lakhuri bricks and is plastered with lime. At present, Jama Masjid along with other popular tourist attractions of Lucknow pioneer the tourism scene of the city.

History

The history of this renowned mosque is quite interesting. In the year 1839, Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah laid the foundation of Jama Masjid in Lucknow as an intention to surpass Jama Masjid of Delhi. However, his dream was left unfulfilled because of his sudden demise. Thereafter, his wife, Malika Jahan Begum, took the charge to finish of the construction of this much-famed mosque in Lucknow. But because of the shortage of funds, the original ambition was curtailed. Despite constructed on a low budget, Jama Masjid has an unrivalled charm.

Architecture

Like most of the popular historical sites in Lucknow, Jama Masjid also boasts an impressive Mughal architecture. It is completely built of Lakhuri bricks and lime. Along with that, the entire structure of the mosque is magnificently adorned with stucco motifs, which adds a different grandeur in the stunning architecture of Jama Masjid. The mosque complex is erected on a square terrace and stands straight on around 260 pillars. Inside the mosque, there is a prayer hall which is rectangular in shape and a beautiful facade of eleven arches that located on the west. The central facade is largest of all with includes an imposing gateway which is also adorned with gorgeous stucco work.

On the top of the prayer hall lies the three pear-shaped domes that are exquisitely ornamented with the inverted lotus of their top. Along with that, these domes are surrounded four-storey minarets placed on either side. The walls and domes include the intricate patterns and mural designs. Along with that, various inscriptions can also be found on the walls of pillars. The tomb of Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah lies on the eastern side, whereas, the Imambara of Malika Jahan is also located on the western side of the mosque complex.

Location Address

Jama Masjid, Tehseenganj, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226004, India.

Visiting Timings

Jama Masjid of Lucknow remains accessible all day a week. One can visit the place at any time from 5 in the morning to 9 in the evening.

Entry Fee

No Entry Fee

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Clock Tower Aminabad, also known as Husainabad Clock Tower, is a prominent landmark in Lucknow with a rich history. Standing at an impressive height of 221 feet, it was built in the late 19th century to commemorate the arrival of Sir George Cooper, making it one of India's tallest clock towers. The tower is adorned with intricate Mughal-inspired architecture and features a beautiful clock on each side.
placeMetadata.address: 202, 2nd Floor, Kalpana Market, Hanuman Mandir Rd, Mohan Market, Swadeshi Market, Aminabad, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226018, India

reviews.reviewText:
The Clock Tower
It is located very near to the Rumi Darwaza. Built in 1881 by the British, this 67 meter high clock tower on the river Gomti is said to the tallest clock tower in India. The tower has European style artwork. The parts of the clock is built of pure gunmetal and the pendulum hangs 14 feet.It is made of red bricks and adorned with intricate stucco work, ornamental plasterwork, and beautiful designs. The clock tower has a square-shaped base, and as it rises, it gradually becomes octagonal.Clock towers were placed near the centres of towns and were often the tallest structures there. As clock towers became more common, the designers realized that a dial on the outside of the tower would allow the townspeople to read the time whenever they wanted. The use of clock towers dates back to antiquity.Clock tower, also known as "ghanta ghar" is a very famous tourist attraction. It was started in the year 1948 and got completed in 1953. The much respected Lal Bahadur Shastri inaugurated the monument. It was a renowned landmark of the city and was built by the British before India got its independence.Explore the history of one of the most iconic buildings in the world: the Elizabeth Tower ‚Äì or as you probably know it: Big Ben. Find out which clock tower in the north of England inspired its design, and what all the different symbols found on the tower mean.

The renowned Hussainabad Clock Tower is another popular tourist spot of Lucknow with its rich heritage and intricate beauty.

The Hussainabad neighbourhood of Lucknow is home to the historic Hussainabad Clock Tower. After Sir George Cooper, the first lieutenant governor of the United Provinces of Oudh, arrived, the Hussainabad Trust constructed it. The bell tower is one of the most exquisite examples of British architecture.

The highest clock tower in India, also known as Ghantaghar, is one of the most popular tourist spots in Lucknow.

About Husainabad Clock Tower
Built in the late 19th century, the clock tower is an architectural marvel and a prominent landmark in the city. The tower's intricate design and construction, including the clock mechanism, are a testament to the craftsmanship of the time.

The clock tower's proximity to the Hussainabad Imambara, another significant tourist attraction in Lucknow, makes it an ideal destination for tourists exploring the city.

Visiting the Husainabad Clock Tower during festivals like Eid, Independence Day, and Republic Day is particularly special. The tower is illuminated with colourful lights, adding to its grandeur and appeal

The Clock Tower in Lucknow, an iconic symbol of the city‚Äôs rich heritage, has unfortunately seen better days. Once a proud landmark, it now stands in a state of neglect. The surrounding area, which used to be well-maintained, is now littered and unkempt, detracting from the tower's historic charm. The structure itself, though still impressive, shows signs of wear, with fading paint and some visible cracks. The lack of proper lighting also makes it less appealing, especially in the evening.

Local authorities seem to have overlooked the need for regular maintenance and preservation of this historic site. It‚Äôs disappointing to see such a significant piece of Lucknow‚Äôs history not receiving the care it deserves. There‚Äôs a pressing need for restoration and better upkeep to bring the Clock Tower back to its former glory and preserve it for future generations to appreciate.

reviews.reviewText:
Indira Gandhi Pratishthan in Lucknow is a stunning venue that boasts beautiful architecture and lush green lawns, making it an ideal spot for various events and exhibitions. With multiple auditoriums of different sizes, this convention center can accommodate up to 1,500 people and offers ample parking space for over 1,000 vehicles. The venue's grandeur and spaciousness provide the perfect setting for cultural celebrations, conferences, and trade fairs.

The architecture is state-of-the-art, with well-maintained grounds and ample parking. The layout is thoughtfully designed, allowing for easy navigation and a great view of the stage and dance floors. The staff is courteous and helpful, ensuring a comfortable experience for guests

I had the pleasure of attending the Medical Expo at Indira Gandhi Pratishthan in Lucknow, and I must say it was an incredibly well-organized event. The layout was thoughtfully designed, making it easy to navigate through the various stalls and exhibitions.

The event showcased a wide range of innovative medical technologies and products, bringing together industry professionals, healthcare providers, and enthusiasts under one roof. The organizers ensured smooth management, from registration to on-ground assistance, creating a seamless experience for all attendees.

Special mention to the informative seminars and interactive sessions that added immense value to the expo. The venue itself was clean, spacious, and well-equipped, further enhancing the overall experience.

Kudos to the team behind this fantastic event! Looking forward to more such expos in the future.

Too many halls and really big space, please ensure you ask the guard at the entrance as to which way to go.

Attended an event at saturn hall, great location, well connected and good parking.

The dining area is very hot in this hall as ac is absent and fans are useless in Lucknow heat.

Good conference hall from outside but need to work on air conditioning
Especially on the first floor
It's looking very beautiful üòç. I visited this place for rojgar mahakumbh 2025 . You can also visit by 26 27 28th of August 2025

A massive recreational centre for public in the heart of the city. Has many different halls and auditorium to organise big events with lush green campus.
It is behind the High court Lucknow bench.

The Indira Gandhi Pratishthan is more than just a "place." It is a dynamic center of gravity for Lucknow and Uttar Pradesh‚Äîa place where important conversations happen, where culture is revered, and where the legacy of a great leader is honored through continuous engagement and progress. It is a symbol of a modern India, deeply rooted in its values yet confidently marching towards tomorrow.

Management need to be some educated and hard working person who looks after this Pratisthan.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Lucknow, the city of Nawabs, is a treasure trove of stunning architecture and lush gardens, making it a photographer's dream. From the intricate designs of the Bara Imambara to the serene beauty of the Gomti Riverfront Park, every corner of this vibrant city offers a unique backdrop for capturing memories. Whether you're wandering through the historic Rumi Darwaza or exploring the tranquil Janeshwar Mishra Park, you'll find countless opportunities to snap that perfect shot that tells the story of Lucknow's rich heritage and culture.

As you stroll through the bustling streets, don‚Äôt miss the chance to capture the grandeur of the Clock Tower Hussainabad, a striking reminder of the city's colonial past. The lush greenery of Dilkusha Garden and the ornate beauty of the Chhota Imambara provide picturesque settings that are sure to impress. With a mix of well-known landmarks and hidden gems, Lucknow invites you to explore its beauty through your lens. So grab your camera and get ready to discover the best photo spots this enchanting city has to offer!

placeMetadata.name: Rumi Darwaza

sources.snippet: Standing at a height of 60 ft, Rumi Darwaza is one of the architectural wonders of Lucknow. It‚Äôs an elaborately designed gateway that serves as an example of Awadhi architecture. If reports are to go by, it was built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-daula to help locals against the famine.
sources.shortName: Finest architectural marvels of Lucknow

sources.snippet: Somewhat better preserved is the Rumi Darwaza, a public gateway, which is the symbol most often used to depict Lucknow in travel literature. There is speculation that it is similar to a portal in Constantinople (now Istanbul)‚Äîin recognition of which the Darwaza was called Kustuntunia in the 19th century. Others have seen in it a resemblance to the Sublime Porte of the Ottomans.
sources.shortName: Fascinating facts about some of the most iconic buildings in Lucknow

sources.snippet: The famed Rumi Darwaza is indeed one of the finest pieces of architecture in the whole of Lucknow. It is said that the design is heavily inspired by a similar gateway that once stood in Turkey and was built by Constantinople. It is 60 feet tall and is also sometimes referred to as the Turkish gate.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rumi Darwaza is a significant historical landmark in Lucknow, standing at 60 feet tall and serving as an emblem of the city. Built in 1784, it showcases intricate Awadhi-style architecture and is associated with the flourishing era of Asaf-ud-Dawlah, known for his patronage of arts and culture. The gateway offers a stunning view and serves as a popular backdrop for nighttime photography due to its brilliant illumination.
placeMetadata.address: 17/11 Hussainabad Road, Lajpat Nagar Colony, Lajpat Nagar, Machchhi Bhavan, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226003, India

reviews.reviewText:
Rumi Darwaza, one of Lucknow‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, stands as a majestic symbol of the city‚Äôs rich Nawabi heritage and architectural brilliance. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula during a period of severe famine, the structure not only provided employment to thousands but also left behind a masterpiece that continues to awe visitors centuries later. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúTurkish Gate‚Äù due to its Awadhi architectural style inspired by Turkish design, the Rumi Darwaza rises to a height of 60 feet, with a striking arched gateway and intricately carved floral motifs adorning its surface.

Sadly, in recent years, the monument has undergone a round of repainting rather than proper restoration. The use of modern paints, rather than historically accurate conservation techniques, has slightly dulled its original charm. Yet, even this cosmetic intervention hasn‚Äôt managed to mask its beauty. The gateway still exudes elegance and grandeur.

What makes Rumi Darwaza even more intriguing is its resemblance to the shape of a traditional necklace ‚Äî and to those familiar with Lucknow‚Äôs textile artistry, it uncannily echoes the layout of a chikan kurta design. It‚Äôs a bridge between architecture and culture, the physical and the artistic. Despite changes over time, Rumi Darwaza continues to be a proud emblem of Lucknow‚Äôs past and present.

Recently Visiting Rumi Darwaza in Lucknow is an awesome old Awadhi architecture. The marvelous carvings and grand design make it a beautiful sight. It resemble to the shape of a traditional necklace and pendant. It's considered one of the proud emblem and most photogenic spots of Lucknow. If you are in Lucknow please don‚Äôt miss here to take a picture. Visit this place in early hours for good pictures and avoid crowd. After Delhi and Agra I found architecturally beautiful city is Lucknow. As the name suggests itself and some people called it the Turkish Gate. Must visit.

1.Architectural Beauty:
Visitors often praise the Rumi Darwaza for its grand design and detailed carvings. Many call it a "masterpiece of Awadhi architecture."

2. Perfect for Photography:
Tourists love clicking photos here. It's considered one of the most photogenic spots in Lucknow, especially in the early morning or at sunset.

3. Historical Importance:
Many people appreciate the deep historical value of the gate. They mention it transports you to the era of Nawabs and Mughal influences.

4. Central Location:
Since it‚Äôs located in the heart of Lucknow, it's easy to combine a visit with other nearby attractions like Bada Imambara and Chota Imambara.

5. Mixed Notes on Maintenance:
Some reviewers feel that while the structure itself is stunning, better maintenance (especially cleanliness around the area) could make the experience even better

Rumi Darwaza in Lucknow is a stunning example of Awadhi architecture. The intricate carvings and grand design make it a beautiful sight to behold. The structure's elegance and beauty are captivating, making it a must-visit spot for anyone who appreciates architectural marvels and photography opportunities. Very impressive.

placeMetadata.name: Bara Imambara

sources.snippet: Bara Imambara is one of the prominent heritage sites in Lucknow, and was built in 1784 by the fourth Nawab of Awadh, Asaf-ud-Daula. The complex is home to Shahi Baoli (stepwell) and an ancient mosque. However, the highlight of this site remains the Bhool-Bhulaiya, which is a complex sequence of labyrinths and has more than 489 interconnected doorways.
sources.shortName: Finest architectural marvels of Lucknow

sources.snippet: Bara Imambara, built by Nawab of Awadh Asaf-ud-Daula, is one of the most important historical monuments in Lucknow. The Imambara complex consists of a baoli (stepwell) and a bhool bhulaiyya, a labyrinth with interconnected doorways. There are over 1024 ways to reach the terrace but only two ways to come back down.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Bara Imambara, also known as Asafi Imambara, is a grand architectural marvel built by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula in the late 18th century. This historical monument in Lucknow features a large mosque, a labyrinth called Bhul Bhulaiya, and a stepwell with running water. The central hall of Bara Imambara is renowned as the largest vaulted chamber globally and is devoid of any woodwork except for its interior galleries.

Historical mugal palace and worship place at Lucknow. The Bhool Bhulaiya in Bara Imambara in Lucknow is a labyrinth of interconnected tunnels, with each path branching into many others and only one leads to the exit. It is a must visit as the exiting the labyrinth will be challenging and time consuming. Place is maintained well and organised crowd management by the authorities are appreciative.

A place with picture worthy views but  mismanaged by authorities

I was born in Lucknow, and I am a local.
Today I visited the Imambara 3rd time in my life, last visit was in 2008 and these are the below things I observed.
1. There is no  baggage or security check. This place is piece of cake for any one with bad intentions or wants to cause havoc.
2. Ticket price for adults is INR 50 which is ok but for visiting the roof area or the bhool bhulaiyaa, a guide has to be hired which will cost minimum INR 100.
3. Before entering the Imambara or the bhool bhulaiya everyone must deposit his/her shoes outside the inner Imambara entrance and the men at the deposit counter will say "jo dena ho dede" which means the price for security deposit is not fixed and they mostly keep shoes and slippers in open. If there is rain the shoes can get wet. There is no proper cloak room.
4. Since taking guide is mandatory for bhool bhulaiya we had to forcefully do so and the guide will take you and show you the various holy things kept in Imambara. The guide that we got was named Raja Hindustani and his diction was not at all clear. He took us on the narrow paths made of the dome of the Imambara without footwear and there was no lights and the floor is broken at places and can cause cuts and bruises. The maintenance of this place is worst I have ever experienced. I will suggest not to take small kids here and that too on a weekend. My 4 year daughter was feeling scared and also this place is not for claustrophobic people.
5. Our guide passed a comment too on my wife which she opposed and yelled at him after which our group consisting of 40 people praised and clapped for my wife as she vented out at the guide who all the group members were forced to follow even though his way of explaining things or tackling crowd was pathetic. Many women came and told my wife " good you shouted at him " as all of the people were frustrated but not speaking up against the unruly behaviour of the guide.
6. Since the roof is all stones and everywhere it is hard and uneven , walking on it for kids is very hard and chances of getting hurt are high.
7. Nevertheless it is a picturesque place and if you hire a proper guide who takes more money your experience can be better but the forced guide system and no light being in the narrow pathways is risky for women.
The forced guide will charge INR 150 for complete tour.

Bada Imambara, the "Pride of Lucknow" is a majestic architectural masterpiece, built by the aristocratic Nawabs many centuries ago. I got the opportunity to visit this place and its entry ticket gives you access to visit other nearby iconic destinations too, like Chota Imambara, Shahi Bauli, Bhool Bhulaiya etc. In the Bada Imambara you are required to deposit your shoes in the shoe counter before entering its many impressive sections. One important point to note is that they don't allow unmarried couples to enter Bhool Bhulaiya without hiring a guide.
Overall, it's a spectacular place to visit in Lucknow!üí´

Bada Imambada in Lucknow is one of the city‚Äôs most iconic monuments and a must-visit for history and architecture lovers. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula, this grand complex reflects the elegance of Mughal and Awadhi architecture, constructed without the use of wood or iron.

The highlight of the monument is the Bhulbhulaiya (labyrinth) ‚Äì a fascinating maze of narrow passages, countless identical doorways, and hidden staircases. Exploring it is both exciting and slightly mysterious, and it‚Äôs easy to lose your way without a guide. Hiring a local guide is strongly recommended, as they not only help you navigate the maze but also share interesting historical stories about the Imambada.

Another marvel is the central arched hall, one of the largest in the world without any supporting beams. Standing inside feels majestic and showcases the genius of 18th-century engineering. The complex also includes the Asfi Mosque and the Shahi Baoli (stepwell), each worth visiting for their design and historical significance.

The site is generally well maintained, with reasonable entry fees, and combined tickets give access to all attractions inside. Weekends and holidays can be crowded, so mornings are the best time to visit. Parking is available outside, and after exploring, you can enjoy authentic Lucknowi food at nearby eateries.

Overall, Bara Imambada along with the famous Bhulbhulaiya is an unforgettable experience ‚Äì a mix of history, culture, and architectural brilliance. A true jewel of Lucknow!

Though we were not allowed in due to a religious event there, the building frok outside looked beautiful. However, the entrance to it, the road leading to it, the adjoining places of interest were extremely dirty and filthy with no maintenance done for years it seems. Such great heritage is totally neglected.

Bara Imambara is not just an architectural masterpiece but also a symbol of Lucknow's historical and cultural tapestry. Whether you're a history enthusiast architecture aficionado or a curious traveler a visit to this monument promises a memorable experience.

It's renowned for its magnificent architecture, including one of the world's largest unsupported vaulted halls. The most famous feature is the "Bhulbhulaiya," a dense, confusing labyrinth on the upper floor. The complex also houses the Asafi Mosque and a stepwell, offering a complete glimpse into Awadhi art and engineering. It's a key landmark that showcases the city's rich cultural heritage. I recommend if you are in lucknow you must visit this marvel

The Hussainabad Clock Tower is truly a beautiful landmark in Lucknow. The architecture is stunning, with intricate details that make it stand out, especially when seen up close. It‚Äôs well-maintained, and the surrounding area has a nice historic charm. Visiting in the evening is extra special ‚Äî the lighting makes it even more picturesque. A great spot for history lovers, photography, or just a peaceful walk while soaking in the old-world vibe of the city.

In the resplendent city of Lucknow, a towering marvel of modernity pierces the sky ‚Äì the illustrious Clock Tower, a masterpiece of Moorish design, erstwhile believed to be the largest in the Indian subcontinent. This magnificent edifice, a symphony of stone and steel, is illuminated by a dazzling array of lamps, its beauty further enhanced by the melodic chime of five bells, whose sweet peals echo through the air. Standing tall at 221 feet, this grandiose structure is an exemplar of traditional British architecture, rivaling the iconic Big Ben of London in both splendor and majesty. Its colossal wheels, a marvel of engineering, surpass even those of its London counterpart.

Conceived by the visionary architect of those times- Richard Roskell Bayne, this monumental clock tower was erected at a cost of two lakhs, funded by the benevolent Trustees of the Husainabad Endowment, who wisely invested the legacy of thirty-six lakhs of rupees bequeathed by the illustrious Muhammad Ali Shah, third King of Oudh. Bayne‚Äôs masterpiece, a testament to his ingenuity, boasts a intricate machinery comprising wrought-iron sides, gun-metal wheels, and hardened steel pinions, precision-crafted to ensure unwavering accuracy.

This majestic timepiece, a true marvel of modern science, stands as a shining beacon, a testament to the confluence of art and engineering. Its grandeur is a reflection of Bayne‚Äôs prolific career, which spanned the construction of bridges, train stations, and bungalows, as well as monumental buildings such as the East India Railway Office, New Market in Kolkata, and Oak Grove School in Mussoorie. His legacy extends to the Thornhill and Mayne Memorial Library and Mayo Memorial in Allahabad, a testament to his enduring impact on India‚Äôs architectural landscape.

Husainabad Clock Tower is a stunning heritage landmark and the tallest clock tower in India. The architecture is remarkable, especially when lit up in the evening. It‚Äôs a peaceful spot for history lovers and photography enthusiasts. The place is also wheelchair accessible ‚ôø which adds to visitor comfort.

Visiting the Bara Imambara was an incredible experience. The architecture is absolutely stunning, with grand arches, intricate carvings, and a beautifully maintained garden that adds to the charm of the place. It‚Äôs not just a monument ‚Äî it feels like stepping back in time. The central hall is massive and awe-inspiring, and the Bhulbhulaiya (labyrinth) is a must-try for a bit of fun and mystery. It‚Äôs a peaceful, clean, and well-kept heritage site, perfect for history lovers, photographers, or anyone wanting a glimpse of Lucknow‚Äôs royal past. Highly recommended if you‚Äôre visiting the city!

The tower is located near other heritage sites like the Rumi Darwaza and Husainabad Imambara, making it an integral part of Lucknow‚Äôs cultural and architectural landscape.

placeMetadata.name: Dilkusha Kothi

sources.snippet: The best thing about the monuments of Lucknow is their diversity as these are built as per not just one or two, but several styles of architecture from all over the world. While the above monuments reflected Mughal, Hindu, European and other styles, Dilkusha Kothi is here to show you the magnificence of the Baroque style of architecture. Saadat Ali Khan, during his rule in the 19 th century, constructed this building, which is a complete replica of Seaton Delavel, an English country house built in 1721.

sources.snippet: The finest thing about the monuments of Lucknow is their diversity since they are constructed according to not one or two but several architectural styles from throughout the world. An often ignored rarely visited Heritage spot in Lucknow. Most tourists head to Imam Bara, Roomi Darwaza, top off with kebabs and leave. This historic baroque mansion which saw great action during the 1857 revolution period should be a must on everyone's calendar. Site facilities are however non existent. Drinking water fountains do not work and the main information centre and souvenir shop is now a glorious outhouse for staff. The lawns are reasonably well maintained and inner courtyards of both structures remain locked without explanation. Old signs of vandalism and brainless love scribbles exist as a reminder that a lot of people don't value Heritage.

Gripes apart, this is a must visit and barely a 10 mins ride from City centre. This hunting lodge cum Summer retreat for the nawabs and British residents alike would have been a vibrant place in the early 19th century. Hopefully the tourism development corporation would better publicize this place and allot a decent budget for better upkeep and maintenance.

Entry is free from sunrise till sunset but you may find the main gate locked till 10 am. Even otherwise, the gate was perplexingly locked with a loose chain which makes visitors squeeze through the gates. Parking is amply available on site for two and four wheelers.

The Tomb of Saadat Ali Khan is a historical monument built in memory of Saadat Ali Khan, the sixth Nawab Wazir of Awadh, who ruled from 1798 to 1814.

This mausoleum also houses the grave of his wife, Murshid Zadi (often referred to as Khurshid Zadi).

The twin tombs are a fine example of Indo-Islamic architecture, showcasing the grandeur and elegance of Awadh‚Äôs Nawabi era.

The structure was commissioned by Saadat Ali Khan‚Äôs son, Ghazi-ud-Din Haider, who demolished his own residence to create this resting place for his father.

The tomb features a large hemispherical dome, intricate stucco work, and a distinctive black-and-white marble checkered floor‚Äîa rarity in this region due to the scarcity of marble.

The surrounding garden and the nearby mausoleum of Murshid Zadi add to its serene ambiance.

Visiting the Maqbara of Saadat Ali Khan in the Qaiser Bagh area of Lucknow was a captivating journey into late-Mughal splendour. The tomb, built by his son Ghazi-ud-Din Haidar, sits majestically on a raised plinth surrounded by neatly manicured lawns and delicate railings, giving it an almost regal air amidst the greenery

placeMetadata.name: The Residency, Lucknow

sources.snippet: Meanwhile, conversations about the schoolboys who walked Constantia‚Äôs hallways are carried on in one of Lucknow‚Äôs most visited landmarks‚Äîthe Residency. The building was the official home of the British resident general at Awadh, and was besieged for more than five months during the revolt of 1857. It was here that the British suffered their worst losses, before recapturing the city on November 17, 1857.
sources.shortName: Fascinating facts about some of the most iconic buildings in Lucknow

sources.snippet: British Residency may not be one of the best preserved monuments in Lucknow, but it is undeniably an important part of its history. Hence, a must visit for every history buff during a Lucknow trip. In 1857, when the city found itself at one of the major centres of rebellion uprisings against the cruel British rule, this place became home to about 3000 British people.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Historical Places in Lucknow: Check Timing & Entry Fee

placeMetadata.description: Historical site featuring the ruins of a refuge for British citizens during the Revolt of 1857.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Residency in Lucknow is a captivating historical site that offers a glimpse into the past, particularly during the tumultuous times of the Revolt of 1857. Nestled amidst beautifully terraced lawns and gardens, this remarkable complex was originally constructed as living quarters for British officials under Nawab Saadat Ali Khan between 1780 and 1800. Overlooking the serene River Gomti, it served as a refuge for British citizens during one of India's most significant uprisings.
placeMetadata.address: VW6G+7P3, Mahatma Gandhi Marg, Deep Manak Nagar, Kaiser Bagh, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226018, India

reviews.reviewText: One of the prominent attractions of Lucknow city. It served as the residence for the British Resident General and has the ruins of a British settlement at the time of the 1857 uprising. Place is clean and huge and has quiet surroundings. You can see a lot of small birds and squirrels and also has a small museum with lots of information on display. Some trees are so huge they will be easily over 200-300 years old. A must visit if you love history!!

Having lived in Lucknow all my life, I had visited The Residency as a child but never truly explored it. Recently, I finally took the time to revisit this historic gem ‚Äî and I‚Äôm so glad I did.

The moment you step inside, you‚Äôre transported to a time that shaped India‚Äôs history. The ruins, still marked with bullet holes and cannon fire, silently narrate the intensity of the 1857 revolt. Each structure within the complex ‚Äî from the Baillie Guard Gate and Treasury to the church ruins and underground chambers ‚Äî holds a haunting charm.

Walking through the wide lawns and shaded pathways, I spent time at the museum, the graveyard, and the many crumbling buildings that once formed the heart of British residency life. The view from the top of some of the structures is breathtaking, and the atmosphere is both peaceful and reflective.

It‚Äôs not just a monument, it‚Äôs a memory ‚Äî of resilience, history, and a city that has seen so much. If you‚Äôre in Lucknow, The Residency deserves your time and attention.

Wow ! What a lovely place. Completely peaceful, historical and full of greenary. It's a place which tell us about 1857 revolt in Lucknow. The remains are well managed and preserved. A long pending bucket list in Lucknow finally ticked off and totally worth the wait. Absolutely peaceful please, very well maintained. History comes alive here. This is a live testimony of strength, resilience and determination of our soldiers in the first ever revolt for our independence. The proof of the revolt in form of cannon marks and bullet marks are everywhere. The museum inside the main building is also worth a visit. You can even purchase from here small guide cum history books on Konark, Goa, Delhi etc. which are limited edition publications of ASI and is not available in the market. Definitely residency is worth a visit if you are a history buff or want a peaceful place to stroll and sit, away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

This mosque is located in the area of Husainabad, Lucknow. The construction of this mosque was started in the year 1839 A.D. by Muhammad Ali Shah, third Badshah of Awadh with the intention to surpass the Jama Masjid at Delhi in size, but after his death the mosque was completed by his wife Queen Malika Jahan Sahiba in the year 1845 A.D.[1]. One can see Indo Islamic architecture. This mosque is opened for Muslims only. The prayer hall is surmounted by three pear-shaped high double domes decorated with an inverted lotus on the top and is also flanked by two octagonal four-storeyed tapering minarets on either side.

Jama Masjid¬†Lucknow

Adding a unique charm in the historical significance of the city of Nawabs, is the famous Jama Masjid in Lucknow. Built by Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah Bahadur in the year 1839, Jama Masjid is one of the oldest historical landmarks in Lucknow. Along with being a popular tourist site, it also serves as an important religious centre in Lucknow for the Muslim community. Despite being compared with Jama Masjid of Delhi, this mosque has gained its own popularity because of its unique architectural design. Unlike Delhi's Jama Masjid, this one is built of Lakhuri bricks and is plastered with lime. At present, Jama Masjid along with other popular tourist attractions of Lucknow pioneer the tourism scene of the city.

History

The history of this renowned mosque is quite interesting. In the year 1839, Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah laid the foundation of Jama Masjid in Lucknow as an intention to surpass Jama Masjid of Delhi. However, his dream was left unfulfilled because of his sudden demise. Thereafter, his wife, Malika Jahan Begum, took the charge to finish of the construction of this much-famed mosque in Lucknow. But because of the shortage of funds, the original ambition was curtailed. Despite constructed on a low budget, Jama Masjid has an unrivalled charm.

Architecture

Like most of the popular historical sites in Lucknow, Jama Masjid also boasts an impressive Mughal architecture. It is completely built of Lakhuri bricks and lime. Along with that, the entire structure of the mosque is magnificently adorned with stucco motifs, which adds a different grandeur in the stunning architecture of Jama Masjid. The mosque complex is erected on a square terrace and stands straight on around 260 pillars. Inside the mosque, there is a prayer hall which is rectangular in shape and a beautiful facade of eleven arches that located on the west. The central facade is largest of all with includes an imposing gateway which is also adorned with gorgeous stucco work.

On the top of the prayer hall lies the three pear-shaped domes that are exquisitely ornamented with the inverted lotus of their top. Along with that, these domes are surrounded four-storey minarets placed on either side. The walls and domes include the intricate patterns and mural designs. Along with that, various inscriptions can also be found on the walls of pillars. The tomb of Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah lies on the eastern side, whereas, the Imambara of Malika Jahan is also located on the western side of the mosque complex.

Location Address

Jama Masjid, Tehseenganj, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226004, India.

Visiting Timings

Jama Masjid of Lucknow remains accessible all day a week. One can visit the place at any time from 5 in the morning to 9 in the evening.

Entry Fee

No Entry Fee

Review of Chattar Manzil

Chattar Manzil, or the ‚ÄúUmbrella Palace,‚Äù is one of Lucknow's most iconic landmarks, embodying the city's Nawabi heritage and architectural brilliance. Constructed in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, it served as the residence of the Nawabs of Awadh and later became a significant site during the Indian Rebellion of 1857.

The architectural style of Chattar Manzil is a captivating blend of Indo-European and Nawabi influences. Its most striking feature is the dome crowned with a unique umbrella-shaped structure, which gives the palace its name. The interiors, though weathered over time, were once adorned with intricate carvings and opulent decor that reflected the Nawabs' grandeur and sophistication. The palace's location along the banks of the Gomti River enhances its scenic appeal, making it a picturesque spot for visitors.

Historically, Chattar Manzil is significant as it served as a strategic site during the First War of Indian Independence. The palace housed revolutionaries who resisted British forces, adding layers of historical depth to its aesthetic allure.

In recent decades, the monument suffered neglect, leading to deterioration. However, government and conservation groups have initiated restoration efforts to preserve its legacy. Today, it stands as a symbol of Lucknow‚Äôs regal past and resilience.

A visit to Chattar Manzil offers a unique experience, combining architectural marvels, historical significance, and cultural richness. It is a must-see for history enthusiasts, architecture lovers, and those seeking to delve into Lucknow's glorious Nawabi era.

placeMetadata.name: Firangi Mahal, Lucknow

sources.snippet: The Firangi Mahal, one of the historical places in Lucknow, is located in the Indira Nagar neighbourhood of Lucknow. The Palace, previously the home of Mr Neil, a French merchant, was a key source of education and establishment for some of the most distinguished Muslim professors. The Firangi Mahal is a significant attraction and an exceptional example of Mughal architecture and Islamic principles.
sources.shortName: These 12 Historical Places In Lucknow Will Make The Mughal Era Come Alive

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Firangi Mahal, nestled in the vibrant Indira Nagar area of Lucknow, is a captivating historical site that reflects the rich tapestry of Mughal architecture and Islamic heritage. Originally the residence of Mr. Neil, a French merchant, this remarkable complex has played a pivotal role in shaping education for prominent Muslim scholars. Its name translates to "European Palace," highlighting its unique origins and connection to European influences during Aurangzeb's reign.

placeMetadata.name: Crown of Constantia

sources.snippet: The restoration of the Constantia required ‚Äúa sense of affection‚Äù apart from the more practical money and planning, said Carlyle McFarland, principal, La Martiniere College, Lucknow.
sources.shortName: Fascinating facts about some of the most iconic buildings in Lucknow

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Crown of Constantia, also known as La Martinere College, is a significant historical attraction in Lucknow. Built during the British rule in India, this grand building showcases Anglican architecture and played a crucial role in the 1857 mutiny. Originally constructed by French Major-General Claude Martin in 1785, it now houses his tomb along with a library, chapel, and an elegant lobby room.
placeMetadata.address: RXQ7+R5R, Martin Purva, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226001, India

reviews.reviewText: This was build as the residence for Frenchman Claude Martin, a wealthy General of the British Army, and the founder of the La Martiniere however, he died in 1800, two years  before its completion in 1802. It presently houses the La Martiniere College as per the will of the General as well as his tomb. The palatial architecture is a visual marvel and one the must visit sites in the city of Lucknow.

When you want to witness the architectural grandeur of the British era, you must make a visit to the Constantia House. It is part of the renowned La Martiniere College, one of the premier educational institutions in the city. The building houses the tomb of Major Claude Martin, the French general who started its construction way back in 1785. Considered to be the largest European funerary monument in the country, the Constantia House exhibits an unusual mix of architectural styles.

placeMetadata.name: Farhat Baksh Kothi

sources.snippet: The wonders of the structure, better known as Kothi Farhat Baksh, are still being unravelled. Its unique feature was rooms that were submerged in the waters of the Gomti River; these rooms functioned as an automatic cooling system for the floors above.
sources.shortName: Fascinating facts about some of the most iconic buildings in Lucknow

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Farhat Baksh Kothi, also known as Martin Villa, is a fascinating historical structure located on the banks of the Gomti River in Lucknow. Built by French Major General Claude Martin in 1781, it features unique rooms submerged in the river that served as a natural cooling system for the upper floors. The kothi was later purchased by Nawab Asaf-ud-daula and renamed Farhat Baksh Kothi due to its reputation for improving health.
placeMetadata.address: 80, Mahatma Gandhi Marg, Kaiser Bagh, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh 226001, India

reviews.reviewText:
The Farhat Baksh Kothi is built adjacent to the Chhatar Manzil, within the same premises. It was built by & was the residence of the French Major General Claude Martin.
Its original name, thus, was Martin Villa.

Legend has it that Nawab Asaf ‚Äì ud ‚Äì Daula used to be frequently unwell; the British Resident recommended him to stay in the Villa, post which his health improved significantly!
It was then that the Nawab named it Farhat Baksh Kothi (‚Äòpleasing mansion‚Äô).

The Farhat Baksh Kothi has Gothic architecture. In the olden days, its ground floor touched the river Gomti because of which it always remained pleasant inside!
Love how the old structures were built so thoughtfully!

Recent excavations have also brought out pillars going deep inside the ground, i.e., a subterranean floor in all probability! I preferred the Farhat Baksh Kothi much more over the Chhatar Manzil.
I could not take my eyes off this beauty, especially its Romanesque roof!

Interesting abandoned building.

From the inscription: General Claude Martin erected a building in Indo-French style at the lowest terrace on the right bank of Gomti river for his own residence in 1781. It was known as "Martin Villa. Later on it was purchased by Nawab Asaf-ud-daula (1775-1795). Nawab Saadat Ali Khan (1798-1814), during his serious illness, was advised by the British resident to shift in this building. He shifted and resumed his health and renamed this building as Farhat Baksh (pleasure-giving). The basement was built to rescue from extremely hot summer as the air waves passing through water turned cool. The building has square designs in Gothic style. The ceilings were having beautiful paintings On the second floor. pillared balcony was built for viewing all around. Later on Nawab Saadat Ali Khan beautified it further with denticulate arches and Awadh style of doors and windows.
Beautiful historic building but its abandoned now

sources.snippet: A different connection to the world is found at the Rauza-e-Kazmain, a replica of the mausoleums of the seventh and ninth Imams in Iraq. Unlike the city‚Äôs other, perhaps better known Imambaras, this one has two large minarets and four domes covered in brass‚Äîas opposed to the more commonly found stone. The ones in the original shrine are covered in gold.
sources.shortName: Fascinating facts about some of the most iconic buildings in Lucknow

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rouza E Kazmain, located in Lucknow, is a significant religious site for Shia Muslims. It is a replica of the mausoleums of the seventh and ninth Imams in Iraq and was built to honor Imam Musa-e-Kazim and Imam Mohammad Taqi. The mausoleum features two large minarets and four brass-covered domes, giving it a unique architectural appeal compared to other shrines in the city.

Of course, there were some ups and downs during the execution phase ‚Äî delays and small confusions here and there ‚Äî but that‚Äôs normal in any project. What matters is that they handled it well and always found solutions without making it stressful for me.

Hello, I had planned to build a house in Lucknow and came across some property designs by RPA (Ravi Prakash Associates). After some research, I got in touch with Mr. Ravi Prakash through his brother, as Ravi often lives abroad. Following our discussions, I paid an advance of ‚Çπ40,000 to initiate the project.

Unfortunately, my experience with RPA was extremely disappointing. Despite following up for several months, the only output I received was a very basic and unprofessional 2D design, which lacked detail and effort. Ravi assured me that it was just the initial version and would be improved, but no further progress was ever made.

Due to the poor communication and lack of professionalism, I decided to discontinue the project. I requested a partial refund‚Äîasking to deduct ‚Çπ10,000 for the basic design‚Äîbut Ravi stopped responding. Initially, his brother mentioned that the refund would be processed after speaking with Ravi, but later I was told the money would not be returned at all.

What‚Äôs more concerning is that I later learned from some of his past clients that this kind of experience is not unusual. It appears that working with clients in Lucknow is not a priority for Ravi, and his approach seems more like a side business. He is very difficult to reach and unresponsive to important discussions.

I‚Äôm not writing this to recover my money but to warn others‚Äîplease be cautious if you plan to work with RPA or Ravi Prakash. Based on my experience, he lacks the dedication and professionalism expected from a reputed architect.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Lucknow, a city steeped in history and culture, is a treasure trove of architectural wonders that reflect its rich heritage. From the majestic Rumi Darwaza, a stunning gateway that dates back to the 18th century, to the towering Clock Tower Hussainabad, which stands as a testament to colonial-era craftsmanship, the city offers a unique blend of styles that tell the story of its past. Each structure, whether it‚Äôs the intricate designs of the Chota Imambada or the historical significance of the Residency, showcases the artistic flair and architectural prowess that have flourished in this vibrant city.

As you wander through Lucknow, you'll discover a mix of traditional and contemporary designs that capture the essence of modern living while honoring the city‚Äôs historical roots. Architectural firms like A+ Design Architects and Elements Design Studio are redefining the skyline with innovative projects that harmonize with the environment. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast or simply curious about the city's charm, Lucknow invites you to explore its stunning buildings and hidden gems that make it a unique destination for all.
